References: <1224.61.247.255.57.1144858083.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>
	<dc538c3f0604120923o4d95c8e1tfb8097e008b8b2a0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1351.61.247.255.57.1144871285.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

Hi Bala!

> if apple releases macosx for free, then u can use it. they would never
> going to release it for free.
>>
>> >just moved to OSX on my laptop - darwin rocks
>
> OSX is not Linux.

I am not sure I understand your response here.

>> great! would appreciate some information on this. How do you rate this
>> against using Linux?
>
> Linux is full loaded with FOSS while OSX is not.
>

OSX has a good set of FOSS software. OSX runs both X11 as well as Quartz
compatible software without any issues. GNU toolchain and GCC has been
ported over so most OSS software should work fine. There have been some
notable OSS software which don't work very well though - examples include
OpenOffice.

To answer Gopalarathnam Venkatesan's query about Sun Java not being
available for Linux - that is not true. Sun Java is indeed available for
Linux, it is just that it is not available for all distributions of Linux.

http://java.com/en/download/manual.jsp

Regards,
Prem

hi,

 > > if apple releases macosx for free, then u can use it. they would never
> > going to release it for free.
> >>
> >> >just moved to OSX on my laptop - darwin rocks

> > OSX is not Linux.

> I am not sure I understand your response here.

OSX is based on BSD Unix. its not Linux. it can use GNU tools but it
is not available for free.
check out
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/oreilly/mac/news/macosx_0301.html
but the articles discussed back in 2001 which has got some outdated
info like macosx runs only apple hardware. except this, u can find
more info related to OSX evolution.

>
> >> great! would appreciate some information on this. How do you rate this
> >> against using Linux?
> >
> > Linux is full loaded with FOSS while OSX is not.
> >
>
> OSX has a good set of FOSS software. OSX runs both X11 as well as Quartz
> compatible software without any issues. GNU toolchain and GCC has been
> ported over so most OSS software should work fine. There have been some
> notable OSS software which don't work very well though - examples include
> OpenOffice.
>

check out
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/oreilly/mac/news/macosx_5things.html

> available for Linux - that is not true. Sun Java is indeed available for
> Linux, it is just that it is not available for all distributions of Linux.

> available for Linux - that is not true. Sun Java is indeed available for
> Linux, it is just that it is not available for all distributions of Linux.

The point which is being made is that Sun Java is *not* FOSS. It is
non-free software. So, if you are saying that Linux is loaded with
FOSS and claim to be using Sun Java, you are using non-free software
for Linux...

From anant at kix.in  Thu Apr 13 10:52:09 2006
From: anant at kix.in (Anant Narayanan)
Date: Thu Apr 13 10:53:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Darwin on Intel and Linux
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f0604121756i2a42224cm511e15df41778dae@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1224.61.247.255.57.1144858083.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>	<dc538c3f0604120923o4d95c8e1tfb8097e008b8b2a0@mail.gmail.com>	<4cba61b90604121005t2a43c1dbhca7abeeb7c2f65f3@mail.gmail.com>
	<dc538c3f0604121756i2a42224cm511e15df41778dae@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <443DE001.60704@kix.in>

Hi Balachandar,

> i never use Komodo. i use the built-in development tools like vi or emacs
> FYI, Adobe provides acrobat reader  which is available for free. check out here
> http://adobe.com/products/acrobat/readstep2.html

> i have sun java and also gnu java. even sun  provides linux version of
> jdk and jre. it is free right.

You've got your definition of "free" wrong here. Just because the
software is free to download and costs nothing doesn't make it free
software. You should call it "freeware" instead.

Free software is when the source code of the software in question is
available to the general public. Adobe reader and Sun Java do _not_
satisfy that condition and are hence termed as "non-free" software.

Regards,
-- 
Anant

Find Freedom, Go Open Source!
http://www.kix.in/
From prem at songbirdtech.com  Thu Apr 13 11:00:43 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Thu Apr 13 11:00:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Darwin on Intel and Linux
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f0604121811q2fc09123p5a2884179df2c901@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1224.61.247.255.57.1144858083.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com> 
	<dc538c3f0604120923o4d95c8e1tfb8097e008b8b2a0@mail.gmail.com> 
	<1351.61.247.255.57.1144871285.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>
	<dc538c3f0604121811q2fc09123p5a2884179df2c901@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1143.61.247.255.57.1144906243.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

>
> check out
> http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/oreilly/mac/news/macosx_5things.html

Actually, ever since Mac OSX Panther came out, the GNU compatibility has
gone up considerably. So the issues mentioned in this linked article are
not all true.

It is my opinion that if Mac OSX is released for generic intel boxes, then
it would really pose a problem for Linux. Mac OSX has a lot going for it -
for one thing it is a good distribution of Unix and has the ability to run
both X11 and Quartz apps. It also does this with far more polish than
Linux..MacOSX also feels much better put together than any distribution of
Linux I have tried so far. Many of the mainstream apps such as MS Office,
Quicken, Adobe and Macromedia products etc all work well on MacOSX.

Regards,
PK

From bhuvan at ubuntu.com  Thu Apr 13 11:04:01 2006

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604121426230.14167-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

> with us.

I did. It was good. They mainly focussed on demonstrating commercial
products, web 2.0 technologies, podcasting, corporate blogging and
couple of open source topics (ruby on rails, rich ruby, contributing
to ubuntu, etc.)

In general, IMO, it was a platform for start-ups to demonstrate their
product and market the product to the possible extent. The way they
organised this two day event is plausible. The organisers and
volunteers have done a wonderful job.

From karuppuswamy at gmail.com  Thu Apr 13 11:14:43 2006
From: karuppuswamy at gmail.com (KaruppuSwamy T)
Date: Thu Apr 13 11:14:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good Tamil support in Ubuntu 6.06
Message-ID: <a1da1e5e0604122244g2418931ey36475a482eb0b4be@mail.gmail.com>

I want to share with you my pleasure of having wonderful Tamil support from
Ubuntu 6.06 (Flight-6). I am able to key in the tamil characters in phonetic
mode without any hassles. Switching between Tamil and English just a click
away. Font rendering also found to be good in Firefox and other
applications. But instead of Sans, we have to select other TSCu_* fonts
available for better support.
 I hope now I have crossed another big *NOT IN GNU/LINUX* excuse. Great to
see this!

Note: I think our list member Mukunth (if am not wrong) was annoying some
times before about this tamil support in Linux. I think he reads this mail
and happy about it.

Here are some screenshots:
http://ubuntuforums.org/gallery/files/3/2/6/0/4/Screenshot_567015.png

From vamlists at gmx.net  Thu Apr 13 11:23:48 2006
From: vamlists at gmx.net (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Thu Apr 13 11:24:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] BarCamp Chennai Experiences
In-Reply-To: <200604130855.00522.lawgon@thenilgiris.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604121426230.14167-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>	<443CC8A2.7000404@gmx.net>
	<200604130855.00522.lawgon@thenilgiris.com>
Message-ID: <443DE76C.8070305@gmx.net>

Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:

>On Wednesday 12 Apr 2006 3:00 pm, Vamsee Kanakala wrote:
>  
>
>> a presentation on Project InfraNET
>>by Vijay Anad (this not about .Net - it's a really cool project
>>to bring IT infrastructure to governement bodies).
>>    
>>
>
>could you elaborate on this - i am interested, but google didnt 
>throw up anything specific
>
>  
>
Sure. Vijay is a Canadian-Indian, trying to bring in a National ID kind 
of infrastructure to India. He says that it's very sad that we don't 
even have an account of the deaths in the lower strata in the society. 
As a first step, he is trying to get the local governments at least have 
a good list of people who are living in their constituencies. Each will 
be given an ID, which can be used for different purposes like voter id, 
ration card id, etc. Also, all government bodies will check with this id 
to provide any kind of service, and keep records based on this id.

What is liked about the project is its scope. It's simply mind-boggling 
to imagine getting an id to every person in this country. Obviously, 
Vijay does a better job of explaining what it is all about. You can 
write to him at  vijay AT leadstep D0T com and find out his plans. He is 
looking for some good programmers to work on his ideas. Anybody 
interested, please write to him. He's passionate about this idea and 
fascinating to talk to.


Vamsee.

From binand at gmail.com  Thu Apr 13 08:30:56 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Thu Apr 13 12:01:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] reply-to
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604121656270.15198-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
References: <50190.61.3.110.134.1144839697.squirrel@thenilgiris.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0604121656270.15198-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604122330i258f4f7x3c707e1f8fd356fc@mail.gmail.com>

On 12/04/06, Bharathi Subramanian <sbharathi@midascomm.com> wrote:
> On Wed, 12 Apr 2006, Kenneth Gonsalves wrote:
>
> > then it needs to be fixed as 'reply-to list'
>
> No. Kindly read - "Reply-To" Munging Considered Harmful.
> http://www.unicom.com/pw/reply-to-harmful.html

A four-year old opinion piece. The author talks about RFC 822, but it
has been superceded by RFC 2822. The URL posted by Kenneth refuted
this one so nicely that I wouldn't bother :)

I just have this suggestion - why doesn't ilugc enable Reply-To to
itself for a month or so and ask the list members themselves to choose
between the two options?

The one big argument I have in favour of Reply-to is that several
times I notice that when I post something on the list, I get replies
that come to me directly. They are usually a follow-up question or
additional information, and I'm sure once two-three such emails are
exchanged, the poster's problem is solved. But this whole exchange
happens off the list, is not archived, and thus valuable infomation is
lost forever.

Binand

Hi Binand and others,

--- Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> The one big argument I have in favour of Reply-to is
> that several
> times I notice that when I post something on the
> list, I get replies
> that come to me directly. 

Same here.

This comes primarily from students. Most of them will
switch to PM mode, but, what they fail to realize is
that other folks are still following the discussion in
the mailing list.

I never encourage people sending me PM, unless its
really off-topic.

> But this
> whole exchange
> happens off the list, is not archived, and thus
> valuable infomation is
> lost forever.

+1

SK

Binand Sethumadhavan wrote:

>The one big argument I have in favour of Reply-to is that several
>times I notice that when I post something on the list, I get replies
>that come to me directly. They are usually a follow-up question or
>additional information, and I'm sure once two-three such emails are
>exchanged, the poster's problem is solved. But this whole exchange
>happens off the list, is not archived, and thus valuable infomation is
>lost forever.
>
>  
>
+1. Though I've gotten used to it now, it's slightly annoying that I 
have to take extra care to remove the person's mail id in Thunderbird 
when ever I do a reply-all. Virtually all other mailing lists munge the 
reply-to header. I don't see to any concerns about that in other lists. 
I think the comfort of just hitting reply outweighs other concerns, if any.


Vamsee.

Hello everybody,

           I have one issue. I have 2 different static IPs configured in my
server. I want to utilise both of the IPs if any of one goes down. For
Example, if u ping google.com, you will get different ip address everytime.
But if you say Whois, it will show you that this is belongs to Google. How
can i set this. In my case i have more than 2 locations  and  do not want to
change their settings each and everytime. How can i do that and how to go
further. Please guide me.

On 4/13/06, Gilbert Raja <gilbertraja@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hello everybody,
>
>           I have one issue. I have 2 different static IPs configured in my
> server. I want to utilise both of the IPs if any of one goes down.


What is connected to the ip? ( web server or mail server..?)

If it is web server set the second ip as the secondary ip for the web
server.

If it  is a mail server point the seconday mx record to the second ip

RS

From binand at gmail.com  Thu Apr 13 10:31:02 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Thu Apr 13 14:01:10 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Single DNS for multiple IP address
In-Reply-To: <5be12c660604130107w3c3951cci9c0e73dc647c0fd8@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5be12c660604130107w3c3951cci9c0e73dc647c0fd8@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604130131n5332c1d0h14c34c9b7040aea5@mail.gmail.com>

On 13/04/06, Gilbert Raja <gilbertraja@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hello everybody,
>
>            I have one issue. I have 2 different static IPs configured in my
> server. I want to utilise both of the IPs if any of one goes down. For
> Example, if u ping google.com, you will get different ip address everytime.
> But if you say Whois, it will show you that this is belongs to Google. How
> can i set this. In my case i have more than 2 locations  and  do not want to
> change their settings each and everytime. How can i do that and how to go
> further. Please guide me.

The way google/yahoo/microsoft do it is by utilizing the services of a
company called akamai (www.akamai.com). Akamai specializes in content
delivery - it makes a best-guess of where on the globe you are and try
to direct you to the nearest datacenter where the content is hosted.
With one webserver and two IP addresses, this is not what you want to
do (unless you have $$$ to burn).

With two IP addresses on the same server, uplinked to two different
ISPs, your choices are limited. You can try stunts like automatically
detecting when one of the links is down and updating your DNS record
accordingly, but the DNS caching works against you.

For the low investment type people, there isn't much of a solution to
this problem except ensuring that your link does not go down.

Binand

On 13/04/06, Kenneth Gonsalves <lawgon@thenilgiris.com> wrote:
> > Sun JRE/J2SE is NOT Free Software
> > Adobe Acrobat Reader is NOT Free Software
> > Realplayer is NOT Free Software
> >
> > They all might be freeware, but that is purely coincidental.
>
> but darwin *is* foss:
>
> http://www.opensource.apple.com/darwinsource/

My comment was specifically about the three pieces of software above
(two were referenced in this thread, the third I added myself).

In any case, part of Darwin's source code is released under APSL v2,
and FSF's opinion of that license can be read at
http://www.gnu.org/philosophy/apsl.html

<quote>
The FSF now considers the APSL to be a free software license with two
major practical problems, reminiscent of the NPL:

    * It is not a true copyleft, because it allows linking with other
files which may be entirely proprietary.
    * It is incompatible with the GPL.
</quote>

(Remember, the first of those - that it required linking against a
non-Free library - is the reason all the GPL fanatics were against the
KDE project, and GNOME's raison d'etre).

Binand

In my case it is a Mail server. Im having inhouse server and 2 MX records.
But i want my people from other location to access my any one of Static IP.
Two IPs are always up. If one IP rejected the request or down or too Busy,
it should automatically switch to another IP. If i ping my server it should
ping both the IPs like google and yahoo.

From binand at gmail.com  Thu Apr 13 13:56:50 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Thu Apr 13 17:26:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Single DNS for multiple IP address
In-Reply-To: <7a7d6df30604130140h79bb84c5s63c50b76283257d0@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5be12c660604130107w3c3951cci9c0e73dc647c0fd8@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130131n5332c1d0h14c34c9b7040aea5@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604130140h79bb84c5s63c50b76283257d0@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604130456s2c92e302tef3b6e836255bd29@mail.gmail.com>

On 13/04/06, R.Subramanian (RS) <rs2003@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 4/13/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > For the low investment type people, there isn't much of a solution to
> > this problem except ensuring that your link does not go down.
>
>
> No. We are running servers on low cost lines.
> With two different ips.
>
> The procedure varies and depends on what is connected to the ip. ( mail
> server / webserver / vpn database etc)

I did read your response in this thread. Let me explain to you the
flaw of that approach.

Say you have www.foo.com with two IPs, IP1 and IP2. You add those in
the authoritative DNS server for foo.com as:

www.foo.com.       86400     IN      A       IP1
www.foo.com.       86400     IN      A       IP2

Now, there is nothing in the RFCs that tells the clients to try these
IPs in any set order, or something that forces them to try all these
IPs. So, you can expect roughly half your clients to connect over IP1
and the other half to connect over IP2. Now you can see that when your
IP1 is down, half your clients will not be able to connect to your
webserver. They wouldn't try the other IP as DNS responses are cached.

Binand

Hello Fellow Ubunteros,

Greetings!!!

Hope by this time you would have known that the Ubuntu Indian Local
Community Team has got the Official Status from the Council. See
http://wiki.ubuntu.com/IndianTeam

We have a few requests as well as announcements to be made.

* Firstly we would appreciate if the GLUG's have their Local Ubuntu Teams
who will be responsible for creating awareness about Ubuntu and Ubuntu-In
community and also distribute the Ubuntu CDs in their Monthly meets or FOSS
Events organised by placing bulk orders. [ http://shipit.ubuntu.com]

* We request you to create a Wiki page for your Local Team on our
ubuntu-in.org website and start posting/contributing. Once you have created
a wiki page kindly link it from http://ubuntu-in.org/wiki/Regional_Teams
For eg. Once you have created a wiki page for your regional team say
[Ubuntu-Chennai] kindly go to the Regional_Teams wiki page mentioned above
and add your team name and link it.

* You can help us in Localisation/translation/Packaging for Dapper as well
as future Ubuntu releases.

* Contribute Articles, Documentations, Frequently Asked Questions /Answers

* Keep giving suggestions to help make Ubuntu better for us and the world.

You can subscribe to ubuntu-in mailing list to get the latest
information: http://lists.ubuntu.com/mailman/listinfo/ubuntu-in


Hang around in our IRC #ubuntu-in @ irc.freenode.net

"Live the Spirit of Ubuntu - Linux for Human Beings"

Regards,

From rs2003 at gmail.com  Thu Apr 13 20:02:08 2006

Subject: [Ilugc] Single DNS for multiple IP address
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610604130456s2c92e302tef3b6e836255bd29@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5be12c660604130107w3c3951cci9c0e73dc647c0fd8@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130131n5332c1d0h14c34c9b7040aea5@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604130140h79bb84c5s63c50b76283257d0@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130456s2c92e302tef3b6e836255bd29@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7a7d6df30604130732g61f6f9f3ve8f2a21ea2742eea@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/13/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:

> response in this thread.


He is connecting mail server. a domain name can have multiple mx
records.andeach mx may be configured to different ip numbers.

>>Im having inhouse server and 2 MX records
Are you having single mail server or two mail servers
and what is mta ( sendmail/qmail or postfix)

If it a sigle system, configure the mail server to handle multiple mail
domains and set the second mx as secondary mail domain and and connect both
ip s to the same machine.

We use 2 different systems with 2 different ips/mx just to ensure that
we dont loose any mails in case of a failure of one line or one
system.Wekeep one as primary and the other as secondary. Fetchmail is
run at a
constant intervals (say 3 minutes) in the primary server to connect to the
secondary.

This is now being offered as a bundled service by most of the guys like
vsnl/satyam etc . They call it  " catchall mails service " They will act as
a secondary server for you.
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Thu Apr 13 07:35:30 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Thu Apr 13 20:05:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux-Broadband prob
In-Reply-To: <20060413045211.41777.qmail@web8709.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060413143531.5260.qmail@web50209.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Karthik,

--- "karthik k.n" <keyankay_007@yahoo.co.in> wrote:
> Yuo i ve got a public address...the problem is after
> installin linux i am not able to connect thru
> windows
> IE...

Dude, get the basics. An OS exists on a separate
partition. At any instant only one OS can run on a
processor. What you do with GNU/Linux has nothing to
do with windoze.
 
Anyways, this is not a windoze $upport mailing list.

I will discuss w.r.t. Fedora Core.

> DNS ip address is 192.168.1.1
> Alternate DNS is 61.1.96.71

Set 61.1.96.71 as your ISP DNS address in
/etc/resolv.conf. No need of 192.168.1.1.
 
 nameserver 61.1.96.71

> gateway is 192.168.1.1
> 
> i am able to ping to it

I meant your DNS IP address, 61.1.96.71.
 
> I am not able to ping yahoo.com

Change your DNS and you should be able to ping
yahoo.com.

SK

From vamlists at gmx.net  Fri Apr 14 15:40:03 2006
From: vamlists at gmx.net (Vamsee Kanakala)
Date: Fri Apr 14 15:40:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] ruby on rails
In-Reply-To: <dc538c3f0604140111m31860a80q46e7ff7ab5ac2e83@mail.gmail.com>
References: <dc538c3f0604140111m31860a80q46e7ff7ab5ac2e83@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <443F74FB.1010503@gmx.net>

balachandar muruganantham wrote:

>can anyone help me setting up ruby on rails framework?
>i dont find any good docs related to this. when i started the server i
>get this error
>  
>
I haven't setup the latest version yet, but some people are reporting 
something of a related error on the rails list. Try putting this in your 
config/environment.rb:

RAILS_GEM_VERSION = '1.1.2'


If this doesn't solve your problem, the please post the same question here:

http://lists.rubyonrails.org/mailman/listinfo/rails

They're very helpful, you'll get an answer almost instantly. If you're 
ready to drink the rails koolaid, welcome to the club:

http://groups.google.com/group/chennairb


Vamsee.

From rs2003 at gmail.com  Fri Apr 14 19:20:59 2006
From: rs2003 at gmail.com (R.Subramanian (RS))
Date: Fri Apr 14 19:21:08 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Single DNS for multiple IP address
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610604130748m2fddac42jed125277ffcd5559@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5be12c660604130107w3c3951cci9c0e73dc647c0fd8@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130131n5332c1d0h14c34c9b7040aea5@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604130140h79bb84c5s63c50b76283257d0@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130456s2c92e302tef3b6e836255bd29@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604130732g61f6f9f3ve8f2a21ea2742eea@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130748m2fddac42jed125277ffcd5559@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7a7d6df30604140650tc66669bw6edc65a0f3005029@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/13/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> True, but I'm curious how you handle this problem for the POP server that
> would presumably run on this mail server.


OK.

This arrangement only ensures that no mails are bounced back in case of a
line failure. But the mail system will be fully functional only after the
lines are restored.

Line failures are resorted quickly now a days. As per our records, whole of
last year, our lines failed 5 times. 4 times it was restored in less than
one hour. One time it was 3 hours.

When the lines failed, the outgoing mails of the users in the lan were
received, and kept in the queue of the primary server. The incoming mails
are received, and kept in the queue of the secondary server. With in an hour
all were cleared.

During all these failures, there was a delay in the mails but NO mail was
missed. The users were able to go on, with out noticing much of a
difference.

Practically, in one whole year, a few hours delay, is a decent compromise to
agree upon for such a low cost lines.
From writetojanani at gmail.com  Fri Apr 14 19:45:48 2006
From: writetojanani at gmail.com (Janani Gopalakrishnan)
Date: Fri Apr 14 19:46:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Share your views with LFY
Message-ID: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>

Hi all,

Greetings from Linux for You (www.lfymag.com) 

In order to increase people-orientation and GNU/Linux users' participation
in LFY, we have decided to introduce a new section (sorry, we are still
racking our brains for the 'perfect' name) in the magazine, where GNU/Linux
users can share their opinions regarding one interesting topic each month.

Every month our team will decide on a question or topic and mail it to
various ILUG mailing lists. We hope that the ILUG members will
enthusiastically share their opinions on the subject. The team picks the
best responses and publishes it in LFY. The answers can be technical,
humorous or radical (you may give a totally new perspective to the topic
being discussed).

This month we've decided to start with the topic, "Why is it that 8 of the
world's top 10 supercomputers are powered by GNU/Linux?"

We request all those who are interested to kindly send in your responses to
this question to Janani (writetojanani@gmail.com) with a CC to Atul
(atul@efyindia.com).

We really hope you are as enthusiastic as we are about this.

Look forward to your responses.

Thanks and regards,

Janani Gopalakrishnan (http://gjanani.googlepages.com) 
Atul Goel (EFY Group, New Delhi)

on LFY.Something like kerneltraffic.

Fortune 500 companies because of foo,bar etc..".

Hi,

Thanks for the really prompt response and for supporting our initiative.

> This month we've decided to start with the topic, "Why is it that 8 of the
> world's top 10 supercomputers are powered by GNU/Linux?"

<Toufeeq>Good topic.If you could give some basic facts which will help
non-supercomupter/clustering geeks then it will be more helpful.Just a
few links will do.This way people who are alien to the subject can
also contribute.</Toufeeq>

Hmm... good idea. But, I would rather not give too many details about 
supercomputers, clusters et al, because then people will begin to think too 
technically. We'd like some radical/humorous responses as well, right?

So, here's what I suggest: I'll give you the list of some of the 
supercomputers that run GNU/Linux and you can Google their names and check 
it out. Sounds ok?

1) IBM Blue Gene/L
2) Silicon Graphics' Columbia
3) ASC Purple
4) Dell Thunderbird
5) Cray Red Storm Cray XT3
6) NEC Earth Simulator
7) IBM MareNostrum
8) Cray Jaguar Cray XT3

> We request all those who are interested to kindly send in your responses 
> to
> this question to Janani (writetojanani@gmail.com) with a CC to Atul
> (atul@efyindia.com).

<Toufeeq>Instead can't we have a general LUG-type discussion on the LUG 
mailing
list and you can just grab the "juicy" bits and put them as an opinion
on LFY.Something like kerneltraffic.</Toufeeq>

Again a good idea, but sometimes the thought of being published might cause 
people to shy away from a discussion! So, let's have this as a discussion on 
ILUG-C, but at the same time, let's be clear on the fact that unless you CC 
the mail explicitly to me and Atul, we will not consider it for publication. 
That way we achieve the best of both worlds: the topic gets discussed on the 
mailing list, and at the same time we won't be scaring away the media shy 
people from this discussion. What say you?

Thanks,
Janani

/sbin/modprobe   saa7134-oss

on  fedora core 5, & mandriva 2006

Fedora the problem gets solved
if you give command

but audio i am getting is delayed.

has anybody faced this problem or is there any direct solution?

	<7a7d6df30604130732g61f6f9f3ve8f2a21ea2742eea@mail.gmail.com>

	<7a7d6df30604140650tc66669bw6edc65a0f3005029@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604150030n175c7ad4v4b858564edaaa1c7@mail.gmail.com>

On 14/04/06, R.Subramanian (RS) <rs2003@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 4/13/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > True, but I'm curious how you handle this problem for the POP server that
> > would presumably run on this mail server.
>
> This arrangement only ensures that no mails are bounced back in case of a
> line failure. But the mail system will be fully functional only after the
> lines are restored.

That's right. And this works only for smtp servers, because the DNS
specifications have special hooks for them (a special MX record, with
priorities associated with each record). It wouldn't work for your
POP/HTTP or any other type of server.

Even then, I'm of the opinion that secondary MX records are practically useless.

> Line failures are resorted quickly now a days. As per our records, whole of
> last year, our lines failed 5 times. 4 times it was restored in less than
> one hour. One time it was 3 hours.

That adds up to 7 hours. Or in other words, 99.92% uptime. Most
Internet-based businesses will laugh me out of their offices if I as
an ISP went to them promising only 99.92% uptime.

> Practically, in one whole year, a few hours delay, is a decent compromise to
> agree upon for such a low cost lines.

The fact remains that it works only for the SMTP protocol, and nothing
else. So you really don't achieve anything - your users still go
without emails for the duration of your downtime.

Binand
From parth.technofreak at gmail.com  Sat Apr 15 13:25:41 2006
From: parth.technofreak at gmail.com (Parthan SR)
Date: Sat Apr 15 13:24:32 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [LFY Discussions]
In-Reply-To: <094201c6605c$49288d90$6200a8c0@JANANI>
References: <20060415063002.86E3C1DB262@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
	<094201c6605c$49288d90$6200a8c0@JANANI>
Message-ID: <4440A6FD.2030303@gmail.com>

When speaking about the applications of Linux and Open Source, the first 
point generally put out is "Servers" and "Super-Computers". Going 
through the list of world's top super computers proves this a lot.

Starting with IBM's Blue Gene, which is said to be capable of performing 
200 trillion calculations per second, Linux has been chosen as the best 
option. The reason that researchers at IBM point out for such a decision 
is the vast and strong Open Source Community. Their main idea was to get 
the feedbacks and inputs from the OS community, so that they can improve 
thier existing facilities. Its great to hear that IBM has started 
preferring Linux rather than its own Unix OS version,AIX. ( Reference: 
http://news.com.com/2100-1001-963285.html)

ASC Purple is another mighty product from the IBM, which is proposed to 
be used for Nuclear Weapon Simulations, employs linux to keep it up and 
running. This is a very good example for Linux being used in such 
mission critical applications. And, why leave IBM MareNostrum. IBM has 
been creating more powerful computing machines and employing Linux in 
them. This is something which should make every Linuxian to feel proud 
enough :)

The list continues, with Dell's Thunderbird ( though I didn't get many 
leads on this one). When trying to get info about NEC Earthlink 
Simulator I got this,

"Clusters, often using Linux running on computers with Intel or AMD 
processors, don't run some jobs as efficiently as more monolithic 
designs. But they work well enough at a low enough price that major 
customers are snapping them up."
(Reference: 
http://news.com.com/IBM+regains+supercomputer+bragging+rights/2100-1008_3-5239777.html)

This has been the prime reason that the super computer creators has been 
sticking with Linux. But, doing more googling for sumpercomputers and 
linux took me to this page : 
http://news.com.com/IBM+regains+supercomputer+bragging+rights/2100-1008_3-5239777.html, 
where its been said that almost 60% of the super computers are running Linux

"Linux now has become so technically powerful that it lays claim to a 
prestigious title--it runs more of the world's top supercomputers than 
any other operating system. "

Mark Seager, assistant department head for advanced technologies at the 
Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, Calif., is quoted 
to have said, "The lab chose Linux partly because it is "open source," 
meaning users can change the code to suit their needs. ".

So, there are three main things conforming to the application of Linux 
in Super Computers - cost factor, community and the open source nature :)



> P.S. Parthan's idea about tagging the discussion mails with [LFY 
> Discussion] is great. However, I don't want to disturb the thread this 
> time. Will remember to tag it from the next discussion onwards.

I started the TAG with my post, hope the same continues :D

-- 
Proud Linuxian and FedoraCore / Ubuntu User

Parthan.S.R

Scope eKnowledge Centre

From rs2003 at gmail.com  Sat Apr 15 16:18:30 2006
From: rs2003 at gmail.com (R.Subramanian (RS))
Date: Sat Apr 15 16:18:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Share your views with LFY
In-Reply-To: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>
References: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>
Message-ID: <7a7d6df30604150348g3b90a9b8ge6e1dced55b1a231@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/14/06, Janani Gopalakrishnan <writetojanani@gmail.com> wrote:
>
>  start with the topic, "Why is it that 8 of the world's top 10
> supercomputers are powered by GNU/Linux?"



There are a number of factors involved in choosing a o/s for a machine.

To my limited knowledge, that includes the application planned to be
deployed on the machine, the underlying processors and other hardware
components, the availability requirements of the application ( mission
critical-ness) the security requirements of the applications, the
compatibility requirements of the partners / contractors / users of the
application etc.



Majority of the super computers are developed and/ or deployed in Govt
Projects and  are funded / supported by Govt agencies.  International
Political currents and political needs are major influencing factors of the
specification of these projects and therefore the specification of the
underlying technologies.



One important factor pertaining to the o/s specification of a super
computer, is the requirement of the source code.



Most of the companies contracted for such projects already have ( or able to
have) their own o/s and source code. (in the grade of IBM, Sun etc). They
are all willing to give the o/s but not the source code.



But the project specifications must have insisted on giving the source code
of all the softwares used in that project. So the contracting companies are
crushed between the options of giving the source code of their proprietary
o/s or develop a new o/s specific for the project and give the source code
of that o/s.



Here OSS  becomes the third option. It saves the contracting companies from
giving away the  source code of their propriety o/s and also  saves a lot of
time in developing a fresh o/s since  oss comes with all the FREEdom to edit
it's code to meet the specific application's requirements. In this situation
OSS commercially is the perfect choice. In spite of the fact that , for such
large projects, money is not a big constrain. ( Bill gate$ might be watching
?..)



Amongst the OSS operating systems, on technical parameters , Open BSD and
Solaris might have scored well for the clean code, security and performance.
( possibly  open Solaris is developed based on these pressures..?)  But on
administrative parameters GNU/Linux might have scored well because of the
large no. of available applications, popularity ( & compatibility )   with
systems of contractors/ partners / associates and users, Easy availability
of trained man power etc.



This must be the reason why GNU/Linux is chosen for most of the latest super
computers.



Comments of the members requested.

On 4/15/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> will laugh me out of their offices if I as an ISP went to them promising
> only 99.92% uptime.


1.Our mail servers are for our in house application and we are not in ISP
business.
2.The QoS commitments ( quality of service ) of Mail ISPs, which are in the
range of 99.99 and so on are only indications and are not enforcable since
they have no legal validity.
3. I follow the management principle KISS for designing and maintaining
technology based solutions.( Kiss - Keep it simple stupid)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KISS_Principle
4.The difference between  99.99 and 99.92 is 0.07 % The probability of you
and me dying this year is 0.62 %. ( actuarial statistics of LIC of india for
a 30 year old male/female). When we are choosing to accept a failure rate of
0.62 for our life itself, why cant we accept a failure rate of 0.07 for our
mail servers..?
5. Don't look in to things only technical. Look around the world.
From vishnuvyas at gmail.com  Sat Apr 15 20:22:48 2006
From: vishnuvyas at gmail.com (vishnu vyas)
Date: Sat Apr 15 20:22:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Share your views with LFY
In-Reply-To: <7a7d6df30604150348g3b90a9b8ge6e1dced55b1a231@mail.gmail.com>
References: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>
	<7a7d6df30604150348g3b90a9b8ge6e1dced55b1a231@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <8e6637b50604150752o68c275a0xdbf95ab99ffc1623@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

 "Why is it that 8 of the world's top 10 supercomputers are powered by
GNU/Linux?"

there are lots of reasons to chose GNU/Linux for supercomputers, but
from some practical experience I've had let me list down a few.

One of the primary reasons, that I've seen is the fact that GNU/Linux
has more exposure than all other variants of unix around. It is
usually a great misconception that super-computers are used by
uber-geeks, sadly thats not true.

Most of the super-computers (the top 8 and the ones that I've worked
on) are run primarily by scientists with a considerable non-cs
background. And the last thing  they would want is to be put up in an
environment thats alien to them. Most of them however are used to
linux at some-level (all thanks to LaTeX). And they are comfortable
with linux. Since most projects are approved by scientists at
top-posts, putting Linux would increases the chances of getting a nod
for the contract rather than say OpenBSD or NetBSD. (chances are high
that most of these people haven't heard about that). Btw, I am not
bad-mouthing scientists here, they are just the smartest people
around, And its not really their line of work to care about
"technicalities" like OS issues.

Secondly, one thing that puts linux ahead of the other free nix's
around is the fact that there are many scientific-libraries that work
just like that on linux. Though most of them have been ported to most
other unixes, the "latest and greatest" version often comes out first
on linux.

Third reason, (though it doesn't necessarily pertain to the top-8
supercomputers, but to smaller ones that are regularly used in some
form of research or the other) is that sometimes, A bigger
super-computer is usually shared between a couple of labs, whereas,
these smaller labs often have their own 16-node compute cluster or
8-node compute cluster. And these clusters are invariably linux
(probably running debian or fedora). The reason there is its a lot
easier to install debian or fedora rather than say openbsd or freebsd
and these people would like to have a "home" environment when the ssh
into the super-computers node.

Other Things that doesn't directly relate to the topic at hand.

1. On Windows :
Many people are under the misconception that windows doesn't fit well
in the super-computing area. But strangely some "HP"
(high-performance) versions are on offer by microsoft. The problem
seems to be that the os chokes on handling extremely high bandwidth
lines, rather than any inherent instability in the os itself.
(weakest-link kinda logic i believe).

2. On Supercomputers
The top-8 mentioned above takes into consideration only
super-computers based on speed. But somehow, i feel its too narrow a
criterion. If you take into consideration like accessibility, storage
area clusters, web-servers (on server farms) etc.. I seriously doubt
wether we will see Linux dominating. (I guess OpenBSD/FreeBSD will
start winning). They are all super computers in their own-right, just
that they don't do massive number crunching in the conventional sense.

Regards
Vishnu Vyas.
--
website : http://vishnuvyas.wordpress.com

On 15/04/06, R.Subramanian (RS) <rs2003@gmail.com> wrote:
> 2.The QoS commitments ( quality of service ) of Mail ISPs, which are in the
> range of 99.99 and so on are only indications and are not enforcable since
> they have no legal validity.

It is actually called an SLA, and is usually a legally binding contract.

> 4.The difference between  99.99 and 99.92 is 0.07 % The probability of you
> and me dying this year is 0.62 %. ( actuarial statistics of LIC of india for
> a 30 year old male/female). When we are choosing to accept a failure rate of
> 0.62 for our life itself, why cant we accept a failure rate of 0.07 for our
> mail servers..?

Good question. You should ask the top management, board members,
shareholders and the likes of the big companies this question.

As far as I'm concerned, my company loses several hundred thousand
dollars every hour of downtime, hence I, as the responsible manager in
the IT department, either meet my SLA or prepare myself for an early
retirement. As simple as that.

> 5. Don't look in to things only technical. Look around the world.

From mugunth at gmail.com  Sun Apr 16 09:52:08 2006
From: mugunth at gmail.com (Muguntharaj Subramanian)
Date: Sun Apr 16 09:52:17 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good Tamil support in Ubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <20060415174019.33604.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <8dd9fd0604151023q298c240fg4d466305418723ac@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060415174019.33604.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <8dd9fd0604152122p6a56c672p5bab82fa94ac21eb@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/15/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> Hi Muguntharaj,
>
> --- Muguntharaj Subramanian <mugunth@gmail.com> wrote:
> > 3. Tamil typewriter keyboard.
>
> In Debian, amongst the TSCII, Unicode and TAB tamil
> keyboard layouts, I prefer to use TAB because it is
> very close to the tamil typewriter layout. Only few
> characters are interchanged.
>
> I think it should be available in Ubuntu.



Dear Sakthi,
TSCII, Unicode & TAB are all character encodings.
We are are talking about keyboard layouts.

The following are the standard keyboards used by Tamils:
1. Tamilnet99 keyboard. ( http://www.tamilvu.org/Tamilnet99/keystand.htm )

2. Anjal keyboard. ( There dont seem to exist an official Anjal keyboard
layout site. A layout of anjal keyboard can be found in this URL:
http://www.tamilanjal.com/mail/ta3.htm)

3. tamil typewriter keyboard (Similary here also there dont seem to exist an
official typewriter keyboard site. A layout of typewriter is found in this
site: http://www.tamilanjal.com/mail/ta2.htm )

Please note that using any of the above keyboard, users should be able to
type in any standard encoding(ie. using tamilnet99 keyboard, user should be
able to type in either Unicode encoding or TSCII or TAB encodings depending
software used for typing).

I am not commenting about the encoding.

So here my question is about the keyboard layout used for typing. When the
Linux distros dont give support to the keyboards that are already used by
the tamils, we cannot Tamil users to adopt linux for their needs.

Imagine a linux distro coming with a new proprietory keyboard for english
instead of the QWERTY keyboard thats being used for english now. I feel its
the same suitation exists in tamil distros related to tamil support.

Regards,
Mugunth

From mugunth at gmail.com  Sun Apr 16 10:46:31 2006
From: mugunth at gmail.com (Muguntharaj Subramanian)
Date: Sun Apr 16 10:46:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Good Tamil support in Ubuntu 6.06
In-Reply-To: <20060416044610.24351.qmail@web50202.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <8dd9fd0604152122p6a56c672p5bab82fa94ac21eb@mail.gmail.com>
	<20060416044610.24351.qmail@web50202.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <8dd9fd0604152216g54670dd8q4080f44eaeca99e5@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/16/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> Hi Muguntharaj,
>
> --- Muguntharaj Subramanian <mugunth@gmail.com> wrote:
> > TSCII, Unicode & TAB are all character encodings.
> > We are are talking about keyboard layouts.
>
> So am I.
>
> > The following are the standard keyboards used by
> > Tamils:
>
> The problem is that each one has come up with their
> own standard, and we need to support everyone.
>
> > Please note that using any of the above keyboard,
> > users should be able to
> > type in any standard encoding
>
> In Debian, I can use any of the keyboard layouts,
> unicode/TSCII/TAB. In simple words, a keyboard layout
> is a key-to-character mapping.
>
> Maybe next time when we meet, I'll show you how one
> can use it in Debian.
>
> Regards,
>
> SK



Dear Sakthikannan,
I am afraid you dont understand the difference between encoding and keyboard
layout.

By the term encoding we mean character encoding. Check this url for meaning
of character encoding. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Character_encoding

When we are talking about ascii/unicode/tscii/tab --> we are talking about
encoding NOT keyboards.
*** Note that encoding doesnt talk about how you type a characte in keyboard
***

Keyboard layout:
keyboard layout is how a user types tamil. -- Understand that keyboard
layouts are not character encoding. Also keyboard layouts are not related to
computers alone. *** Keyboard layouts existed in typewriters even before
computers are invented ***

When we talk about terms QWERTY, tamilnet99, Anjal, typewriter keyboard
layouts --> we are talking about keyboard layouts. How the keyboard is
physically present in the keyboard.

Also note that:
In computers using any keyboard layout, we can make the software print any
encoding.
for example we can use tamilnet99 keyboard layout to type tamil in either
TSCII/Unicode/Tab ... encodings.
(Check this downloads page for such softwares for windows:
http://thamizha.com/modules/mydownloads/viewcat.php?cid=3 )

So comparing character encoding with keyboard layouts is like comparing
apples with oranges.

So I hope you understand what I mean by keyboard layouts. With this contect,
please let us know what tamil keyboard layouts are supported in Ubuntu.
(Will a person trained in typewriter institute to type tamil able to type
tamil in the same way in Ubuntu)

Regards,
Mugunth

On 16/04/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > Please note that using any of the above keyboard,
> > users should be able to
> > type in any standard encoding
>
> In Debian, I can use any of the keyboard layouts,
> unicode/TSCII/TAB. In simple words, a keyboard layout
> is a key-to-character mapping.

Shakti: A keyboard layout is the way the keys are distributed on a
keyboard. The standard ones you see, QWERTY, is probably the most
popular one too (though I have seen some AZERTY/QWERTZ keyboards here
in Europe). Unicode or TSCII are NOT keyboard layouts.

Binand

From logulinux at gmx.net  Sun Apr 16 15:10:22 2006
From: logulinux at gmx.net (Logu)
Date: Sun Apr 16 15:10:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mailserver configuration help
Message-ID: <002a01c66139$cc120140$140110ac@LOGUCO>

Hi,

We have a mail server at our california office and there are about 25% of 
mail users in California and the rest 75% are in india office. We get lot of 
large mails to some of the aliases. And since most users in the alias are in 
india and to avoid downloading of the same mail by them we have setup a 
mailserver in India office and forward a single mail to it and distribute it 
from there.

This becomes some what difficult to manage users and alias file on both 
mailservers. Is there a better way of doing this. Also is it possible to 
configure the mailserver at India in such a way that if a user from India 
sends mail to an alias, the mails to the users in India should be locally 
delivered and mail to the users in california should be delivered through 
mailserver at california. The mail id should be of same format to all users.

We have qmail + ldap at california and sendmail in India.

Your suggestions are welcome.

Thanks
-logu

From animeshs at gmail.com  Sun Apr 16 15:29:53 2006
From: animeshs at gmail.com (Animesh Singh)
Date: Sun Apr 16 15:30:02 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mailserver configuration help
In-Reply-To: <002a01c66139$cc120140$140110ac@LOGUCO>
References: <002a01c66139$cc120140$140110ac@LOGUCO>
Message-ID: <e8fef13b0604160259w67c0b68cve67eec8c9d3d44db@mail.gmail.com>

Afternoon Logu,

We have a mail server at our california office and there are about 25% of
> mail users in California and the rest 75% are in india office. We get lot
> of
> large mails to some of the aliases. And since most users in the alias are
> in
> india and to avoid downloading of the same mail by them we have setup a
> mailserver in India office and forward a single mail to it and distribute
> it
> from there.

<snip>
for this check up with riverbed.com product. It has something which  really
optimise the WAN bandwidth by keep track of the data getting transferred
between locations.


This becomes some what difficult to manage users and alias file on both
> mailservers. Is there a better way of doing this. Also is it possible to
> configure the mailserver at India in such a way that if a user from India
> sends mail to an alias, the mails to the users in India should be locally
> delivered and mail to the users in california should be delivered through
> mailserver at california. The mail id should be of same format to all
> users.
> We have qmail + ldap at california and sendmail in India.
>
<snip>
Yes you can achive the same at both the ends.
         a. Qmail ( use the "mailforwardingaddress" in Qmail LDAP. )
         b. Sendmail ( use the complex user routing to set the rules: this
will be achieved by setting local user routing + remote user routing for
specific user you which the e-mail to be routed. )

Animesh.

From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Mon Apr 17 10:50:04 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Mon Apr 17 10:50:13 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Share your views with LFY
In-Reply-To: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>
References: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>
Message-ID: <c293dd340604162220h458adb33j10a3db975f2ecbba@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 4/14/06, Janani Gopalakrishnan <writetojanani@gmail.com> wrote:

> Every month our team will decide on a question or topic and mail it to
> various ILUG mailing lists. We hope that the ILUG members will
> enthusiastically share their opinions on the subject. The team picks the
> best responses and publishes it in LFY. The answers can be technical,
> humorous or radical (you may give a totally new perspective to the topic
> being discussed).

My take is a little cynical one on why big companies use Linux and not
Windows or OSX or *NIX.

> This month we've decided to start with the topic, "Why is it that 8 of the
> world's top 10 supercomputers are powered by GNU/Linux?"

There are many _business_reasons_ why people opt for Linux on
Supercomputers rather than a proprietary operating system.

First, Consider how a supercomputer is constructed.Take the case of
IBM's "Blue Gene" the No.1 among the top 10 list of supercomputers.
Blue Gene is not a "computer" per se. It's a computer architecture
specification. More details on Wikipedia. The Blue Gene architecture
basically refers to how a "compute node" is architectured in the
complete supercomputer. The supercomputer is complete when many such
compute nodes are put together to operate as a single coherent unit.

Each compute node has one or more CPU's on it.When you go in for a
proprietary Operating System(say Windows) the licensing is usually
done "per cpu".When you go out to build a supercomputer with say a 100
compute nodes on it ,it means you will need to purchase 100 licenses
of a proprietary OS for the 100 CPU's and in Blue Gene's case its 100
X 2 as it's a SMP based system.

If you take the CU-11 system[1] based on Blue Gene architecture which
comes with 65536 nodes it really makes no sense to run Windows Server
2003 on it and incur unnecessary OS costs.Linux is commercially free
and there is no per-cpu licensing cost so it really makes business
sense on choosing Linux than Windows or any other proprietary version
of UNIX.

That's the cost part of running Linux, now a few technical advantages.
* Linux has the best SMP support among the free *NIX's.It's much
better than the *BSD's hence the reason why "Big-Iron" computer makers
prefer Linux.Solaris supposedly has better SMP support on Sparc.

* Customizing the linux kernel is easy considering the amount of
available kernel engineers in the FOSS world.Also the linux kernel
allows the linking of proprietary binaries to it which means the
modifications(IP) done by IBM for it's special hardware can still be
retained.

* Threading model: the 2.6 version of the linux kernel has a very
optimized threading model for parallel computation.The 1:1 threading
model of 2.6 with increased support for more more number of processes
and the use of the NTPL threadinf model really gives Linux the edge.

* NUMA: (Non-Uniform Memory Access) Another killer feature required
for Grid based systems made it's way into the 2.6 kernel.Learn more
about NUMA from Wikipedia[2]

How does FOSS Benefit from Supercomputers running Linux ?

* Companies like SGI and IBM contribute back code which they consider
will be important for them.It's purely business.
- IBM has a huge team working on I/O Subsystem's.Guess where I/O plays
a HUGE part ? Supercomputers..
- SGI gives back XFS code under the GPL. Guess what SGI Supercomputers
use as their filesystem ?
- Support for Infiniband made it to the Linux kernel at a blazing
speed.Guess what is used as the netrworking interconnect between
compute nodes.

* Remmember that the user-space software of the supercomputer is *NOT*
FOSS or is no way connected with free software.Who would want
protien-folding capabilities in the linux kernel ? This User-space
software is what is of prime importance in a supercomputer.In the case
of supercomputing this is usually math-crunching libraries and other
special libraries which are required for a specific
task(protien-folding).The user-space s/w is usually interlinked with
non-GPL free software like MPI(http://open-mpi.org) or mpich.  Non-GPL
(BSD based) implementations are available which can be used for
commercial purposes.In fact MS Server 200X(whatever) will be shipping
with the mpich libraries(C++ bindings for MPI).  To make Microsoft
ship it's first open-source package is really remarkable,this proves
how superior the free supercomputing libraries are.These libraries
usually come with shared memory management(ROMIO) and networking
libraries which can be customized to one's needs.

On the whole the Supercomputer-Linux relationship is a purely Business
one.FOSS contribution is just a side effect.

References:
[1] http://www.research.ibm.com/bluegene/BG_External_Presentation_January_2002.pdf
[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Uniform_Memory_Access

-Toufeeq
--
blog @ http://toufeeq.blogspot.com

From sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in  Mon Apr 17 05:48:54 2006
From: sriram at ae.iitm.ac.in (p.sriram)
Date: Mon Apr 17 11:19:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Share your views with LFY
References: <042f01c65fcd$eff19840$6200a8c0@JANANI>
	<c293dd340604140808x6d301650h9b667855ae6d75ed@mail.gmail.com>
	<065b01c65fd7$79781cc0$6200a8c0@JANANI>
Message-ID: <loom.20060417T071453-756@post.gmane.org>

ok, we have had some discussions, let me add my views / facts.

8 of top 10 of the top500 supercomputers TODAY are linux based. was not like
this historically. if you go back, say 5 years (yeah, some of us have been
interested in top 500 for that long, heck, maybe even longer), vendor flavours
of unix was king. ibm, sgi etc were big players, so aix, irix and such figured
prominently. the sponsors then were the same government laboratories and there
was no issue with source code. users were quite happy (well, maybe, maybe not)
with vendor supplied non-open-source os machines as long as the parallel tools
ran as per user expectations. it was common for vendors to tweak their
networking code and parallel tool (mpi) code, but as hardware and network
architechture kept changing, this was more and more tricky. also, specialty
networking like myrinet and infiniband added its own twist to this tale. sorry,
but i believe that the shift to linux is not for any real 'technical merit'
reason but just incidental. high performance users dont really want to see the
networking source code - they want to use parallel tools like mpi and want their
code to run FAST. in any case, the top500 listing is based on linpack benchmark
using mpi (only), so parallel performance using mpi is all that counts.

there was also some comment about param padma. param padma is an ibm p-series
(risc) smp box based machine - basically ibm supplied hardware with some cdac
special networking. the previous param 10000 was a similar construct with sun
hardware. cdac's contribution in both cases was in special networking. the
'real' indian entry into the top 500 (no longer current) was from imsc
(matscience) with its xeon linux cluster. of course, now we have more entries,
including the centre for biochemical technology delhi (i guess institute of
genomics blah blah is the correct name).

sriram

From binand at gmail.com  Mon Apr 17 08:34:47 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Mon Apr 17 12:04:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Backup Tool
In-Reply-To: <a54a308e0604160238u35fc1c1bh824f98d3ad5892e7@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1145166019.8763.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<a54a308e0604160238u35fc1c1bh824f98d3ad5892e7@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604162334s2b95fd00j2073b0f072be55ec@mail.gmail.com>

On 16/04/06, Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:
> Thanks for the tools info :). So now, i have 3 tools to test  tomorrow
> (Monday)
>
> 1) Amanda
> 2) Mondo
> 3) Konserve
>
> Will get back as i progress.

Good. Before implementing the solution, you should also think about
the following points.

1. How Confidential is the data? You should have the same data access
policy for the backups that you have for the actual data.
2. Assuring the Integrity of the data, by recording MD5/SHA1 checksums.
3. Availability of the data - if the master copy of the data crashes,
how much downtime can you suffer? Do you need the backup to be
restored within minutes or hours or days?

The above three together are sometimes known as the CIA principle (and
are not restricted just to backups). Apart from these,

1. Retention period. You cannot keep old data forever - storage,
outside of google, is not infinite. You need to draw a line somewhere
and decide that you wouldn't store data older than so many days.
2. Offsite backups - do you need those? What if a fire destroys both
your production and backup copy?
3. How often do you need full backups and how often do you need
incremental backups?

Binand

No mail is missed and a few hours of delay in whole year :- is a good enough
mailing system for own use for a medium sized enterprise and companies with
budgetary limitations.
That may not be acceptable / appealing for companies in ISP business
or companies with a good budget or MNCs.

>>Good question. You should ask the top management, board >>members,
shareholders and the likes of the big companies this >>question.

>>As far as I'm concerned, my company loses several hundred >>thousand
dollars every hour of downtime, hence I, as the responsible >>manager in the
IT department, either meet my SLA or prepare myself >>for an early
retirement. As simple as that.

I understand. My experience with clients abroad are also the same.
While i personally  would not want to agree to most of their paranoid
specification/ requirements, the money they pay shuts up all my personal
opinions.

> 5. Don't look in to things only technical. Look around the world.
> And...?


While designing / architectureing a system/network / program or a project ,
be conscious on the fact that the external factors can also determine the
success or failure of the project. I have experienced this. You can also see
many technically well designed systems not successful because of external
factors, while technically unsound things becoming super hit. ( simple
example linux & win)
From ashokgautham at gmail.com  Mon Apr 17 13:09:10 2006

From zenmurugan at gmail.com  Mon Apr 17 13:12:31 2006
From: zenmurugan at gmail.com (Senthil Murugan)
Date: Mon Apr 17 13:12:43 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Mailserver configuration help
In-Reply-To: <002a01c66139$cc120140$140110ac@LOGUCO>
References: <002a01c66139$cc120140$140110ac@LOGUCO>
Message-ID: <409b0b770604170042x400ddde3h63fa81718572a51@mail.gmail.com>

>
> We have a mail server at our california office and there are about 25% of
> mail users in California and the rest 75% are in india office. We get lot
> of
> large mails to some of the aliases. And since most users in the alias are
> in
> india and to avoid downloading of the same mail by them we have setup a
> mailserver in India office and forward a single mail to it and distribute
> it
> from there.



This becomes some what difficult to manage users and alias file on both
> mailservers. Is there a better way of doing this. Also is it possible to
> configure the mailserver at India in such a way that if a user from India
> sends mail to an alias, the mails to the users in India should be locally
> delivered and mail to the users in california should be delivered through
> mailserver at california. The mail id should be of same format to all
> users.
>
> We have qmail + ldap at california and sendmail in India.
>
> Your suggestions are welcome.


 You can go for the Qmail at your India Office or make sendmail to use LDAP.
Manage the accounts centrally via LDAP.  This will reduce your job is
configuring your alias settings.

For ex, your LDAP alias may contain:

ou=alias1,dc=yourcompany,dc=com
alias1 <alias1@yourcompany.com>: user1, user2, user3,
alias1_in@india.yourcompany.com

Once this is set, this will forward your mails to your india mail
server(Which is configured to use LDAP)

Create another alias in the same LDAP with:
ou=alias1_in,dc=yourcompany,dc=com
alias1_in <alias1_in@india.yourcompany.com>: user4, user5,user6

This will forward mails to your india.yourcompany.com users

Hope this solves your difficulty in managing the accounts.

But still you need to think it of for sending the mails locally when the
mail is sent to alias from India...

Regards,
Senthil Murugan
From binand at gmail.com  Mon Apr 17 09:53:33 2006

	<7a7d6df30604130732g61f6f9f3ve8f2a21ea2742eea@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604130748m2fddac42jed125277ffcd5559@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604140650tc66669bw6edc65a0f3005029@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604150030n175c7ad4v4b858564edaaa1c7@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604150553n11a80d0eqd5313c3cf51a22e7@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604151418j64a701e7o40083b18b541f85a@mail.gmail.com>
	<7a7d6df30604170026j62438254g703cbb05b06d33b2@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604170053if0b8219we9cc700859732383@mail.gmail.com>

On 17/04/06, R.Subramanian (RS) <rs2003@gmail.com> wrote:
> No mail is missed and a few hours of delay in whole year :- is a good enough
> mailing system for own use for a medium sized enterprise and companies with
> budgetary limitations.
> That may not be acceptable / appealing for companies in ISP business
> or companies with a good budget or MNCs.

Yep, we are both saying the same thing.

The availability expectation v/s cost of implementation graph tends to
have an asymptote at 100% availability. It costs 0 to implement a
system which is never online :-) but infinite to implement one that is
online all the time. So one should make trade-offs and decide on the
kind of availability one needs (which would tell one how much money
one should spend) . If one is running a multimillion dollar mission
critical appserver farm, it pays to spend several grand on having a
99.999% availability system, but it might not be worthwhile doing that
for a company intranet webserver.

Binand

PS: Figuring out where, on the availability spectrum, does the email
system with the blackberry server that top management uses, reside is
left as an exercise to the reader.

Use X -configure instead. It'll drop an xorg.conf in your home dir. Edit that 
later to suit your preferences, but it'll usually be enough to work on.

Hi Ashok,

--- "Ashok Gautham J." <ashokgautham@gmail.com> wrote:
> Again i tried reading the handbook and yet even
> after doing everything
> there, it said eth0 not found, but realtek eth
> chipset which i use  worked
> on all other distros.

At this instant, it didn't strike you to send a query
to ilugc?

> So i was forced to reinstall Ubuntu, 

Its called "running away from the problem". You would
have learnt something if you did do some
troubleshooting at this instant :) 

Next time when you get stuck with Internet
configuration, note the output of the following
commands:

 /sbin/lsmod
 /sbin/ifconfig -a
 /sbin/route -n
 cat /etc/resolv.conf

Note, you can redirect output to a file:

 /sbin/lsmod > lsmod.txt

> like it but that i want
> to be more geekish.

Sure. 

When you go through a learning curve, you will hit
road bumps. Its natural. But, only when you persevere
you will see light at the end of the tunnel.

> Any help would be appreciated
> Also i could do quite a lot if somebody could help
> me with xorgconfig

You can use "xorgcfg" which will open a graphical
display for configuring your X settings.

Regards,

SK

From srinivasg at esntechnologies.co.in  Mon Apr 17 20:55:02 2006
From: srinivasg at esntechnologies.co.in (Srinivas G.)
Date: Mon Apr 17 20:55:53 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Simple Block Driver (RAM DISK) - Console Crash (specific
	case)
Message-ID: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FCDCC@mail.esn.co.in>

Dear All,

I developed a simple ram disk driver. It is working fine. 

But I am facing a new problem (console crash) when I try to run the "ls"
command on a mount point after removing the disk with out unmounting
(see the below - How I am removing the ram disk after mount without
unmounting).

Please find the attached source. I am using the following configuration.
--> x86 system with Fedora Core 3 installed (IA-32 Architecture)
--> Running 2.6.x kernels like 2.6.10, 2.6.12 and 2.6.14 on the same
system.

To reproduce the "console crash error" you just have to follow exactly
the next steps:

1) Copy the attached files to your system 
2) Build the sbd.ko file using the attached Makefile (make)
3) Load (insert) the module into the kernel space (insmod sbd.ko)
4) wait a few milli seconds to create the device node and format the
device (mke2fs /dev/sbd0)
5) mount the device (mount /dev/sbd0 /mnt)
6) copy some files into the mount point (cp *.c /mnt)
7) un mount the device (umount /mnt OR umount /dev/sbd0)
8) then again, mount the device (mount /dev/sbd0 /mnt)
9) remove the mounted device (compile the app.c file [cc app.c] then run
the ./a.out which will remove the mounted device) You can easily
understand by seeing the code.
10) cd /mnt
11) run ls (which shows the errors messages - see attachment mes_log
file)
12) run again ls - console crash 

SEE THE BELOW TWO CONDITIONS WHERE I AM NOT ABLE TO SEE THE CONSOLE
CRASH.

1)	After mounting the FDD, I removed the floppy with out un
mounting (The floppy disk has already some files in it).
2)	If I perform the above procedure WITH OUT STEPS 6, 7 and 8.

Could any one explain why the problem occurs?
If I am wrong please correct me.

Thanks in very advance.

Thanks and Regards,
Srinivas G

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Apr 17 09:22:40 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Apr 17 21:52:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Simple Block Driver (RAM DISK) - Console Crash (specific
	case)
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FCDCC@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <20060417162240.96755.qmail@web50208.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Srinivas,

--- "Srinivas G." <srinivasg@esntechnologies.co.in>
wrote:
> But I am facing a new problem (console crash) when I
> try to run the "ls"
> command on a mount point after removing the disk
> with out unmounting

You should never do this. Always unmount the disk
before removing it:

1. If there is caching of disk write data, then
removing the disk without unmounting it will not cause
the data to be flushed. So, data integrity is not
assured.

2. Driver data will be in an unknown state if not
cleaned up properly.

> Please find the attached source. 

Argh! Don't send attachments to e-mails sent to
mailing list. Bad etiquette. Please post it in
pastebin.com and send a link.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

http://mail.yahoo.com 
From trshash84 at gmail.com  Mon Apr 17 22:24:54 2006
From: trshash84 at gmail.com (T.R.Shashwath)
Date: Mon Apr 17 22:24:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Post gentoo install
In-Reply-To: <5580629a0604170032l4de50d4fqf171d1cb7056dd23@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5580629a0604170032l4de50d4fqf171d1cb7056dd23@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200604172224.54463.trshash84@gmail.com>

Oh, another tip:

On Monday 17 April 2006 13:02, Ashok Gautham J. wrote:
> I use a Samsung Syncmaster 773s, 17 inch monitor, i do not know my video
> card, if intel i865g is one, then i have it
> Also it would be nice if somebody with a similar config gave me stepwise

Don't worry about the monitor, but the i865g works off the i810 driver and 
chipset, which in turn means that it should work with xorg without too much 
trouble.

Just remember to enable it in the kernel: Enable Device Drivers->Character 
Devices->/dev/agpgart and the Intel 440LX/BX/GX, I8XX and E7x05 chipset 
support under agpgart. Also, Direct rendering manager in the same page and 
the Intel cards below that (unless Xorg still comes with its own DRI - 
someone else will correct me on this, I hope). I'd suggest that you compile 
these into the kernel instead of mucking around with modules. You're never 
really likely to need to remove your display driver during runtime! :-)

Shash
-- 
"Where shall  I  begin, please your Majesty ?" he asked.
"Begin at the beginning,", the King said, very gravely, 
"and go on till you come to the end: then stop."

From srinivasg at esntechnologies.co.in  Tue Apr 18 10:29:45 2006
From: srinivasg at esntechnologies.co.in (Srinivas G.)
Date: Tue Apr 18 10:30:27 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Simple Block Driver (RAM DISK) - Console Crash
	(specificcase)
Message-ID: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FCDE6@mail.esn.co.in>

Dear SK,

SK Wrote:
> You should never do this. Always unmount the disk
> before removing it:
> 1. If there is caching of disk write data, then
> removing the disk without unmounting it will not cause
> the data to be flushed. So, data integrity is not
> assured.
> 2. Driver data will be in an unknown state if not
> cleaned up properly.

I understand it removing a mounted device will lead to inconsistent
data. But, in case of a removable media this may happen. Right?

I am trying to simulate a REMOVABLE MEDIA (FLASH MEDIA) driver
environment. This is an attempt to understand what to handle on surprise
removal of a mounted Flash Media disk.

I am not writing any data to the disk after mounting the device before
removing it with out unmounting the device. If I write any data to the
device then I should COMPULSARY unmount the device.

> > Please find the attached source.
> 
> Argh! Don't send attachments to e-mails sent to
> mailing list. Bad etiquette. Please post it in
> pastebin.com and send a link.

Please find the sources at the following link.
http://pastebin.com/666569

Animesh Wrote:
> Are you running this code on uni processor or smp?
I am running this code on a uni processor system.

Could you please suggest me? 

Thanks and Regards,
Srinivas G

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Tue Apr 18 13:55:37 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Tue Apr 18 13:55:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Backup Tool
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610604162334s2b95fd00j2073b0f072be55ec@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1145166019.8763.1.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	<a54a308e0604160238u35fc1c1bh824f98d3ad5892e7@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604162334s2b95fd00j2073b0f072be55ec@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560604180125v13decff4ib5356a2a8031a5fa@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 4/17/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 16/04/06, Chakkaradeep C C <chaks.yoper@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Thanks for the tools info :). So now, i have 3 tools to test  tomorrow
> > (Monday)
> >
> > 1) Amanda
> > 2) Mondo
> > 3) Konserve
> >
> > Will get back as i progress.
>
> Good. Before implementing the solution, you should also think about
> the following points.
...
> 1. Retention period.
> 2. Offsite backups
> 3. How often do you need full backups and how often do you need
> incremental backups?

Interesting points.  I would like to add that rsnapshot and rdiff-backup
(pretty easy to find on google) are excellent candidates for continuous
incremental snapshot backups.  Storing the last 14 days of daily
snapshots is easy peacy and requires surprisingly little disk space
(ofcourse, it also depends on how active your file systems are).

We use rdiff-backup to snapshot ~3TB of data and it works great.
rdiff-backup is highly recommended.

Both systems work only on HDDs and not on tapes.

- Raja

You know that we want to shift to Linux, we are developing softwares . For
this we need text editors, tools for creating tables. On window platform we
are using Macromedia Dreamweaver which creates tables and also edits php
codes and creats database in MySql. For developing softwares in  Linux we
need editor and tool equal to Dreamweaver.

can perform the functions of Dreamweaver in linux which is compactable to
PHP, MySql.

We tried NVU, which does not work with PHP but with only HTML. Therefore not
able to write PHP code on NVU and store in  MySql.Though NVU has all
the good features of Dreamweaver it has no use for Linux .

Please let us know an appropriate tool which can be used for developing
softwares on Linux.

nope - bluefish, quanta, screem, nvu are all aids which assume that the
user is a professional competent in html, css, javascript, databases etc
etc - dreamweaver assumes that the user knows little or nothing of these
things. Migrating the average 'web programmer/designer' from dreaweaver 
to any of these tools is an excercise in futility - the only way a person
would migrate would be if he had to pay personally for his copy of
dreamweaver ;-)

Lets be realistic - there are some things that foss still cannot do. As i
mentioned in another mail on this thread - we are very very far from
developing anything like corel draw.

regards

Subject: [Ilugc] Open Source equivalent for Dreamweaver

Hi,

On 4/18/06, balachandar muruganantham <mbchandar@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Check the post on "Software for 3D/2D Artists,
> > Designers, etc.":
> > http://www.linuxforum.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=53452
>
> the links didnt tell about open source equivalent for Dreamweaver.

This might be slightly OT for this thread but(anyway) I found Active
Grid's[1] AppBuilder[2] a very versatile software package for
developing web applications.Best thing is, it's cross-platform and
100% suited for LAMP development.

Though it's not a Dreamweaver-killer it seems to be a
jack-of-all-trades when it comes to LAMP development(ships with
webserver and MySQL integrated with the IDE) and provides a end-to-end
solution.Feedback at my workplace was very positive with LAMP
dev-newbies.Also it works on Linux,Windows and Mac.

Disclaimer:
I don't work for Active Grid. :-)

Links:
[1] http://activegrid.com
[2] http://www.activegrid.com/what/applicationbuilder.php

-Toufeeq
--
blog @ http://toufeeq.blogspot.com
From r.damodharan at yahoo.co.in  Tue Apr 18 15:10:07 2006
From: r.damodharan at yahoo.co.in (Damodharan Rajalingam)

Subject: [Ilugc] GNU/Linux install on HP Pavilion PC

Message-ID: <20060418141007.54300.qmail@web31808.mail.mud.yahoo.com>



Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote: >From Venu:

So i want to make partitions by myself .
Is there any linux distro available which boots from
CD and which allows me to amke partitions.
Could u please provide me some help in doing this.
 I had the same problem when I wanted to install Debian on my Dell Inspiron laptop. I used GParted LiveCD to partition the C drive. I shrinked the size of C drive using GParted and then installed Debian in my laptop. You can get teh gparted livecd here
 http://gparted.sourceforge.net/livecd.php
 
 Cheers
 Damodharan

On 4/14/06, Vamsee Kanakala <vamlists@gmx.net> wrote:
> balachandar muruganantham wrote:
>
> >can anyone help me setting up ruby on rails framework?
> >i dont find any good docs related to this. when i started the server i
> >get this error
> >
> >
> I haven't setup the latest version yet, but some people are reporting
> something of a related error on the rails list. Try putting this in your
> config/environment.rb:
>
> RAILS_GEM_VERSION = '1.1.2'

i have updated with above line and now it worked. thanks

>
> If this doesn't solve your problem, the please post the same question here:
>
> http://lists.rubyonrails.org/mailman/listinfo/rails
>
> They're very helpful, you'll get an answer almost instantly. If you're

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Tue Apr 18 09:48:43 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Tue Apr 18 22:19:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] *Standard* Tamil encodings for GNU/Linux
Message-ID: <20060418164843.47890.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

Firstly, thanks to all for the clarification between
keyboard layout and character encoding. 

I would like to know your views/preference for Tamil
character encodings: TAB, TSCII, Unicode, any other. I
am using QWERTY keyboard on Debian Sarge 3.1r0a.

I am able to input tamil characters on the
terminal/browser/abiword if I set character encoding
to Unicode. TAB only works with abiword.

But, the catch with unicode is that letters that get
tagged with "oo" or "ooo" are represented in a very
different manner compared to what we use in writing.
Is this acceptable?

This illustration gives the notation used:
http://members.tripod.com/~peacecraft/infomining/tamiluni.htm

Examples: &#2991;&#3009; &#2991;&#3010; 
          &#2965;&#3009; &#2965;&#3010;

The correct representation is provided in TAB
encoding. 

Any thoughts?

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

>Afternoon Srinivas,
>
>You gave a try to "noapic" boot ?

I guess that is not a problem with no hardware related and is not while
booting. The problem is when he loads the block driver module ands tries
to simulate the removable media through (Kernel interfaces) its results
in a crash.
