From binand at gmail.com  Wed Apr 19 07:48:07 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Wed Apr 19 11:18:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] *Standard* Tamil encodings for GNU/Linux
In-Reply-To: <20060418164843.47890.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20060418164843.47890.qmail@web50214.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604182248h21a7bd6eo4d6a550d7ab2b5b4@mail.gmail.com>

On 18/04/06, Shakthi Kannan <cyborg4k@yahoo.com> wrote:
> But, the catch with unicode is that letters that get
> tagged with "oo" or "ooo" are represented in a very
> different manner compared to what we use in writing.
> Is this acceptable?

I don't claim expertise on this topic, but my understanding is that
Unicode doesn't actually specify how different glyphs should be
rendered on screen. Unicode abstracts each written unit - letters,
your oo/ooo, numerals, punctuation marks etc. - and leaves the actual
rendering of these units to the application used.

Binand

From animeshs at gmail.com  Wed Apr 19 11:57:00 2006
From: animeshs at gmail.com (Animesh Singh)
Date: Wed Apr 19 11:57:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Simple Block Driver (RAM DISK) - Console
	Crash(specificcase)
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FCF2B@mail.esn.co.in>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FCF2B@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <e8fef13b0604182327o73b5bb18m8d9c327d0b8db9ca@mail.gmail.com>

Morning Mukund,

I guess that is not a problem with no hardware related and is not while
> booting. The problem is when he loads the block driver module ands tries


It is noting to do with booting.

to simulate the removable media through (Kernel interfaces) its results
> in a crash.


appreciate your concern.

If you will see the call trace: It usually happens in atomic() state, and on
top of it when irq() is disable().. i.e. 1. and as irq() is not reentrant...
so it make your system hangs.

Namely, when "noapic" option is passed symmetric io mode is not entered and
all IRQs appear as "XT-PIC" in /proc/interrupts.

Animesh.

>From: ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in
>To: skrhce2005@hotmail.com
>Subject: Welcome to the "ilugc" mailing list
>Date: Wed, 19 Apr 2006 16:36:45 +0530
>
>Welcome to the ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in mailing list! Indian Linux Users'
>Group - Chennai/Madras is an informal group of Linux and other free
>Unix users in the city. It coalesced in mid-1998, and is still going
>strong. Meetings are held every month. More details and directions can
>be found at the ilugc website: http://www.chennailug.org
>
>Before posting on the ILUGC mailing list please read the following on
>how best to ask your questions on mailing lists. Its well worth the
>read and will prove useful for any mailing list.
>
>http://catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html
>
>
>ILUGC mailing list guidelines:
>
>1. Technical queries may be posted to this list but you are likely to
>    get a better response on linux-india-help@lists.sourceforge.net.
>    More information on that list is available here:
>    http://www.linux-india.org
>
>2. Please avoid flaming on this list.
>
>3. Please trim your replies and use quoting appropriately.
>
>4. Many users find HTML posts annoying so please post messages on this
>list
>    in plain text.
>
>5. Please avoid posts that are not related to Linux and Open Source
>    related topics.
>
>6. When you _have_ to send mail that is off-topic remember to prepend
>    an [OT] or [Off-topic] tag to the subject.  Similarly if the mail
>    involves something commercial please prepend a [Commerial] tag.
>
>7. Please try to wrap your lines at around 72 chars.
>
>8. Avoid cross posting.
>
>
>To post to this list, send your email to:
>
>   ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
>
>General information about the mailing list is at:
>
>   http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc
>
>If you ever want to unsubscribe or change your options (eg, switch to
>or from digest mode, change your password, etc.), visit your
>subscription page at:
>
>   http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/options/ilugc/skrhce2005%40hotmail.com
>
>
>You can also make such adjustments via email by sending a message to:
>
>   ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in
>
>with the word `help' in the subject or body (don't include the
>quotes), and you will get back a message with instructions.
>
>You must know your password to change your options (including changing
>the password, itself) or to unsubscribe.  It is:
>
>   genius05
>
>Normally, Mailman will remind you of your ae.iitm.ac.in mailing list
>passwords once every month, although you can disable this if you
>prefer.  This reminder will also include instructions on how to
>unsubscribe or change your account options.  There is also a button on
>your options page that will email your current password to you.

On Wednesday 19 Apr 2006 5:25 pm, Bharathi Subramanian wrote:
> LJ: Speaking Tips from the Big Leagues:
>
> http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/8985 -- Being a track session
> chairman at the recent LinuxWorld Conference allowed Rob Reilly
> to see what goes on behind the scenes as people prepare for
> lectures and presentations. Here, he shares some important
> lessons you don't want to learn the hard way.

one tip from my experience in speaking at the chennai lug: the linux 
machine was not working, so I borrowed a laptop from the audience - 
dont even know what operating system was on it. My slides were in 
S5 format (html+css) which will run on any operating system 
whatsoever as long as it has a browser
--

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Wed Apr 19 08:50:19 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Wed Apr 19 21:20:29 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [GLV] "Quilt", Saturday, April 22, 2006, IIT-M
Message-ID: <20060419155019.77503.qmail@web50202.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

We will be having a GLV session this Saturday, April
22, 2006 at 1500 hrs IST at CSD #320, IIT-M. 

 http://www.chennailug.org/location-tenet.php

I will be introducing you to "Quilt".

Quilt is a tool to manage patches in project code
development/documentation. The session will be a
tutorial with illustrative examples on how to use
quilt.

The project webpage is at:

 http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/quilt

The tutorial and the code samples that I have written
can be downloaded from:

 http://shakthimaan.com/downloads/glv/quilt-tutorial/

The documentation is released under the GNU Free
Documentation License.

Thanks to Ashok Raj (Intel), Thomas Petazzoni (Enix),
and Jordan (AMD) for their feedback regarding the
tutorial.

SK

Shakthi Kannan

Message-ID: <44472828.5070900@gmail.com>

Hello every1,
installed gentoo 2006.0 successfully and removed all traces of 'jannal'..
now, i hav a teeny weeny but an irritating problem, the scroll whell of 
my ps/2 mouse doesnt work, though it worked in ubuntu. I am pasting a 
part of my xorg.conf file pertaining the mouse.

Section "InputDevice"

# Identifier and driver

    Identifier  "Mouse1"
    Driver      "mouse"
    Option "Protocol"    "PS/2"
    Option "Device"      "/dev/input/mice"
    Option "ZAxisMapping" "4 5"
# Mouse-speed setting for PS/2 mouse.

#    Option "Resolution"        "256"

# When using XQUEUE, comment out the above two lines, and uncomment
# the following line.

#    Option "Protocol"  "Xqueue"

# Baudrate and SampleRate are only for some Logitech mice. In
# almost every case these lines should be omitted.

#    Option "BaudRate"  "9600"
#    Option "SampleRate"        "150"

# Emulate3Buttons is an option for 2-button Microsoft mice
# Emulate3Timeout is the timeout in milliseconds (default is 50ms)

#    Option "Emulate3Buttons"
#    Option "Emulate3Timeout"    "50"

# ChordMiddle is an option for some 3-button Logitech mice

    Option "ChordMiddle"

EndSection

Any hints...?


Sudharshan S

Had some hands on the tools which i mentioned.

1) Amanda
>

I didnt try this tool becoz the docs said that it is for tape drives. I am
still not clear whether it is for tape drives or also can take backups in
normal hard disks.

2) Mondo
>

This tool was excellent. I had got feedback that the earlier verisions had
some problem, but the current stable version is kewl. It takes a backup of
the source as a compressed iso and puts it in any medium you specify. Here
too, am not sure whether Monda can do incremental backups every day or hour.

3) Konserve
>

This is a very small tool. It can be used in home to backup few files. In an
Office or Enterprise Environment, i dont think ths will be useful.

I would be happy to get feedback on Amada and Monda usage, if people are
using it for their backups.

From toufeeqh at gmail.com  Thu Apr 20 20:14:50 2006
From: toufeeqh at gmail.com (Toufeeq Hussain)
Date: Thu Apr 20 20:14:58 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [RFC][Announcement] LiveURL's
Message-ID: <c293dd340604200744p6be532a7lb2778a31d049d241@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

We at InfyLUG, the Infosys[1] Linux User Group have been working on a
Firefox extension called LiveURLs [2] which lets users create links to
specific content on web pages. The concept is based on a technical
whitepaper[3] on web technologies published by InfyLUG and which will
be presented as a poster[4] at the 15th World Wide Web Conference[5]
in Edinburgh, Scotland.

Some benefits of LiveURL's:
    * Sharing selected content on web pages is just a right click away.
    * Peer - Peer Sharing - no centralized entity required.
    * Usable in the same manner as existing URLs.
    * Browsers which do not support LiveURLs still show the whole page.

The code and technology[6] is still in a POC stage with the
implementation-standard details not finalized.  The source code,
licensed under the GPL, can be picked up from CVS [7].  We welcome
suggestions, brickbats, praise and most importantly bug reports [8]. 
Please join the liveurls mailing list [9] for discussion on further
development of this extension.

We hope to garner support for this concept and to see it as a default
feature in all browsers.

[1] http://www.infosys.com
[2] http://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/2400/
[3] http://www.infosys.com/technology/live-urls.pdf
[4] http://www2006.org/programme/paper.php?id=p156
[5] http://www.www2006.org
[6] http://liveurls.mozdev.org/tech.html
[7] http://liveurls.mozdev.org/source.html
[8] http://liveurls.mozdev.org/bugs.html
[9] http://www.mozdev.org/mailman/listinfo/liveurls

More coverage:
http://knutties.livejournal.com/24270.html (The full story)
http://www.infosys.com/events/international-www-conference.asp

Thanks,
Natarajan Kannan & Toufeeq Hussain,
InfyLUG, Infosys Linux Users Group,
www.infosys.com
--
blog @ http://toufeeq.blogspot.com

From rajasuperman at gmail.com  Fri Apr 21 07:45:30 2006
From: rajasuperman at gmail.com (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Fri Apr 21 11:15:40 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need your suggestion for buying Laptop
In-Reply-To: <20060421051609.17814.qmail@webmail61.rediffmail.com>
References: <20060421051609.17814.qmail@webmail61.rediffmail.com>
Message-ID: <92f9a9560604202245k66b47aa1v4290744d940ecd94@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

On 21 Apr 2006 05:16:09 -0000, Nagappan L <nagappan_l@rediffmail.com> wrote:
> I am planning to buy a Laptop, which is Linux compatible. I am RHCE certificate. My flavour is Redhat.
>
> I got some info from my friends, that Centrino processor is not that much compatible. Only AMD support Open source fully.
>

F.U.D.  All x86 CPUs are very well supported in Linux.

> My budget is around 50k. Going to purchase it from UK in June (through my friend). I need an model which should not require upgradation for atleast three years.

EU is typically not that much cheaper than India.  Laptops are
significantly cheaper in the USA and Singapore.

> Please suggest me the following:
>
> 1. Which Make (Acer or Toshiba or HP)
> 2. Model No
>

A laptop is more than just the CPU, RAM, HDD and other specs. 
Ergonomics plays a huge role in deciding on a laptop.  I suggest that
you purchase the IBM/Lenovo Thinkpad laptops.  Nothing comes close to
Thinkpads on usability, rugged construction and ergonomics.  Ive known
Thinkpads to last 5 years without problems.

I own a Dell Latitude, but had to replace the keyboard (keys went soft
and unresponsive), lcd panel hinges broke (and cracked the
motherboard), and the battery had to be replaced.  All within 1 year
of use.  I dont recommend Dell laptops.  Ive reviewed several Acer,
Toshiba and HP/Compaq models, and am thoroughly unimpressed.

A lower end Thinkpad R51 costs some Rs 38,000 and includes a Celeron
CPU, 512MB RAM, 40GB HDD, DVD/CDRW, 14.1" LCD, WiLAN, etc. and no
software.  The machine is also fairly light weight and portable.

If you can afford it, go for the lighter Thinkpad T series.

- Raja

PS: I dont work for any of the laptop companies!
From binand at gmail.com  Fri Apr 21 08:12:42 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Apr 21 11:42:51 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need your suggestion for buying Laptop
In-Reply-To: <92f9a9560604202245k66b47aa1v4290744d940ecd94@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20060421051609.17814.qmail@webmail61.rediffmail.com>
	<92f9a9560604202245k66b47aa1v4290744d940ecd94@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604202312qd4a1253tc4d9a693dfd5db61@mail.gmail.com>

On 21/04/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
> > My budget is around 50k. Going to purchase it from UK in June (through my friend). I need an model which should not require upgradation for atleast three years.
>
> EU is typically not that much cheaper than India.  Laptops are
> significantly cheaper in the USA and Singapore.

On the other hand, if you purchase the laptop in the UK and export it
overseas within 15 days of purchase, you are eligible for a VAT
refund. The VAT in the UK is 17.5% and the refund on a laptop costing
?600 can be significant.

Check out www.dixons.co.uk and www.argos.co.uk to sample the kind of
prices and models available on the UK high street. Also, look at
individual vendors' websites for their offerings too.

> A laptop is more than just the CPU, RAM, HDD and other specs.
> Ergonomics plays a huge role in deciding on a laptop.  I suggest that
> you purchase the IBM/Lenovo Thinkpad laptops.  Nothing comes close to
> Thinkpads on usability, rugged construction and ergonomics.  Ive known
> Thinkpads to last 5 years without problems.

Well said. In my professional career, I have used laptops from (the
erstwhile) Compaq, Sony, Dell and IBM/Lenovo - nothing even remotely
comes close to the Thinkpads in terms of usability and ergonomics.
Windows users can possibly be flustered by the lack of the hot key,
but the laptops more than compensate for that with Access IBM and all
the other features IBM provides. I am now on a T43 which is simply
fantastic.

> If you can afford it, go for the lighter Thinkpad T series.

The T43p is the latest, lightest and greatest.

Binand
From binand at gmail.com  Fri Apr 21 08:20:32 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Fri Apr 21 11:50:41 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need your suggestion for buying Laptop
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610604202312qd4a1253tc4d9a693dfd5db61@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20060421051609.17814.qmail@webmail61.rediffmail.com>
	<92f9a9560604202245k66b47aa1v4290744d940ecd94@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604202312qd4a1253tc4d9a693dfd5db61@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604202320x7915e88dga928097a2a5d9d7d@mail.gmail.com>

On 21/04/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On the other hand, if you purchase the laptop in the UK and export it
> overseas within 15 days of purchase, you are eligible for a VAT
> refund. The VAT in the UK is 17.5% and the refund on a laptop costing
> ?600 can be significant.

Forgot to mention that:

1. If your friend is coming to India with TWO laptops (one of his own)
- you will have to pay customs duty in India. Unless there is a person
in your friend's party without a laptop, you will end up paying 200%
or something duty (or a hefty bribe).

2. Laptops (and PCs) sold in the UK will have en-GB as the
default/only locale and more importantly, the UK keyboard layout. This
keyboard layout has significant differences from the US layout which
you see in India, though one can adjust to it easily. For example, the
@, #, | and ~ keys (all important to the Linux user) are NOT where you
expect to find them.

Binand

+1 for Thinkpads. I have an R51 (couldn't afford the T series - someday,

Message-ID: <d2a92d610604210050l57dccdfdt12b847855ae335a5@mail.gmail.com>

On 21/04/06, Vamsee Kanakala <vamlists@gmx.net> wrote:
> It survived some very bumpy rides on a bus to and fro my hometown.

Thinkpads have a very handy feature for the frequent traveller, called
IBM Active Protection System. It protects the HDD from shocks and
vibrations. From the manual:

<quote>
The IBM(R) Active Protection System protects your hard disk drive when
the shock sensor inside your ThinkPad(R) computer detects a condition
that could damage the drive, such as system tilt, excessive vibration,
or shock. The hard disk drive is less vulnerable to damage when it is
not operating; so the system stops it from spinning, and may also move
the read/write heads of the drive to areas that do not contain data.
As soon as the shock sensor senses that the environment is stable
again (minimal change in system tilt, vibration, or shock), it turns
the hard disk drive on.
</quote>

Binand

From ilamparithi at gmail.com  Fri Apr 21 14:05:26 2006
From: ilamparithi at gmail.com (ilam parithi)
Date: Fri Apr 21 14:05:33 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Need your suggestion for buying Laptop

	<d2a92d610604210052v3c06a09exfa048010831f624c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <eb80c88f0604210135n7a579943jaa0945cdab54cdc0@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

I recently bought an IBM THINKPAD R51 2887 MQ6 Laptop. I did some googling
for Linux compatibility of laptops. I found that thinkpads are famous among
the linux community.

I didn't intend to upgrade in near future. So i wanted a model with
          512 MB RAM
         DVD Writer
         80 GB Harddisk
         Centrino processor

Thinkpad R51 is the one model that has all these features(almost) and within
my price range.

But i had to make some compromises.

Thinkpad R51 features
         512 MB RAM is DDR (not DDR2)
         DVD writer
         60 GB HD (instead of 80GB i wanted)
         1.7 GHZ Centrino processor
          No pre-installed OS ( no problem here)

Cons :

     No Windows key
     No wide screen
     You cannot increse the volume more than certain extent. (of course you
can attach an external speaker or headphone)

     I have bought this for 56,500 in chennai. If my budget is slightly
higher i would have gone for higher end models in thinkpad but nothing else.

Other laptops

       Featurewise i am impressed by Hp pavillion laptops though i don't
have any hands on experience on them.

        A recent model in lenova has all the above features but no DVD
writer. It has a built in camera.

PS :

         I have installed Fedora Core 4 and it is working fine. And waiting
for Fedora Core 5 DVD.

Best of luck,

Regars,
M.Ilamparithi

Hi,

On 4/21/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> On 21/04/06, Raja Subramanian <rajasuperman@gmail.com> wrote:
> > EU is typically not that much cheaper than India.  Laptops are
> > significantly cheaper in the USA and Singapore.
>
> On the other hand, if you purchase the laptop in the UK and export it
> overseas within 15 days of purchase, you are eligible for a VAT
> refund. The VAT in the UK is 17.5% and the refund on a laptop costing
> ?600 can be significant.

The process is not as simple as it sounds.  You cannot waiver the VAT
at the store itself, i.e. no duty free shopping available in stores. 
You must pay the full price at the store and claim the VAT back later.
 The VAT counter at Heathrow never opened its doors on time (for me
atleast), and I never managed to get a VAT refund.  There is the
option of filling up some forms and doing the entire process through
the post, but thats an entirely different can of worms.


> Check out www.dixons.co.uk and www.argos.co.uk to sample the kind of
> prices and models available on the UK high street. Also, look at
> individual vendors' websites for their offerings too.

Large retalier stores in the USA www.cdw.com, www.newegg.com, offer
great deals and rebates.  Its much easier to find/compare laptops on
the cdw.com website than ibm.com itself!  However, the lower end
models are simply not listed in their catalogs.  The savings are big
only if you are looking for higher end machines like the T or X series
Thinkpads.

IMO, the best place to purchase a lower end R series Thinkpad is India.

- Raja

From sudharsh at gmail.com  Fri Apr 21 18:33:48 2006
From: sudharsh at gmail.com (Sudharshan S)

Subject: [Ilugc] A kernel query
Message-ID: <1145624628.9068.2.camel@tuxbox.ubergeek>

hello evry1,
whats the role of 'usblp' kernel module, and where does it reside, i
mean which option do i have to enable to compile it as a module

Sudharshan S

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Fri Apr 21 07:43:43 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Fri Apr 21 20:13:59 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] A kernel query
In-Reply-To: <1145624628.9068.2.camel@tuxbox.ubergeek>
Message-ID: <20060421144343.72547.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Sudharshan,

I will answer this w.r.t. 2.6.x Linux kernels:

--- Sudharshan S <sudharsh@gmail.com> wrote:
> whats the role of 'usblp' kernel module, 

USB printer support in the Linux kernel.

> and where
> does it reside, 

drivers/usb/class/usblp.c in the kernel sources.

> i
> mean which option do i have to enable to compile it
> as a module

CONFIG_USB_PRINTER=y in Device Drivers->USB
Support->USB Printer Support.

Regards,

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

Message-ID: <d2a92d610604210809l4244de80jd9965b31d6bad30e@mail.gmail.com>

On 21/04/06, Parthan SR <parth.technofreak@gmail.com> wrote:
>    Does the same customs problem hold true in the case of getting it from
>    Singapore ?? I plan to get one from Singapore through my cousin. Can't she
>    get more than one from there as shes planning to get one for her ? My

The import duty is imposed by India. The rule is that one laptop per
passenger for personal use can be imported without any paperwork or
payment, but anything more than that needs to be cleared via customs
after paying the necessary duty which I think for electronic goods is
150 or 200% (we are assuming that a laptop will not fit in the
duty-free limit of Rs. 25,000).

As I said, if your friend is flying into Mumbai or Hyderabad (or any
of the Kerala airports), she could pay bribes far less than that and
bring the laptop in, but my personal opinion is that customs officers
at Chennai are generally a honest lot.

Binand

On 21/04/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
> The import duty is imposed by India. The rule is that one laptop per
> passenger for personal use can be imported without any paperwork or
> payment, but anything more than that needs to be cleared via customs
> after paying the necessary duty which I think for electronic goods is
> 150 or 200% (we are assuming that a laptop will not fit in the
> duty-free limit of Rs. 25,000).

What do you know? Our customs department has a website :)

This one is illuminating:

http://www.cbec.gov.in/cae/customs/cs-act/notifications/notfns-2k4/cs11-2k4.htm

And hence, my numbers change to (http://www.cbec.gov.in/cae/trvlers-info.htm )

"The goods over and above the free allowances shall be chargeable to
customs duty @ 40% + an education cess of 2% i.e. to say the effective
rate is 40.8%."

So if the customs guys get hold of it, your 50k laptop becomes a 70k one.

Binand

From arpit04 at gmail.com  Sat Apr 22 03:32:25 2006
From: arpit04 at gmail.com (Arpit Sud)
Date: Sat Apr 22 13:27:42 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] CD burning on command prompt
In-Reply-To: <44432A60.1030609@midascomm.com>
References: <44432A60.1030609@midascomm.com>
Message-ID: <73a10bbf0604220032w2605b514yb56a339225c3ab30@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/17/06, Deepak <deepakd@midascomm.com> wrote:
> When i checked CD size, it displayed 500KB.

Did you try reading the CD size in M$ Window$, then see this:
http://aumha.org/win5/a/xpcd.php
Quoting from the link:
<Quote>
Explorer Properties shows the CD as the wrong size.

There appears to be a bug in Windows Explorer, such that when you put
in a disk that contains multiple ISO Sessions, Properties shows the
size of the files in the last session only, which may be very
misleading. This applies to multi-session disks burned with third
party software, as well as the native Win XP system.

</Quote>

Hi,

The European-Union funded FLOSSWorld project aims to enhance the level
of global awareness related to FLOSS among various sectors like
industry, academia, government, etc. As a part of this project, we
plan to conduct a series of surveys related to FLOSS, to understand
the impact and usage of FLOSS among developers, employers, government
officials and educational institutions across India.Please refer to
www.flossworld.org for more details about the FLOSSWorld project.

We are in the process of collecting contacts in order to circulate the
survey questionnaires. We have collected a number of contact addresses
from the internet and from references obtained from our regional
workshop participants.Give your experience in FOSS related
activities.We seek your help in reaching out to as many as people as
possible.Could you please mail back any contacts you know of among the
developer, e-government, academia and employer community, to whom, you
think, we can send the survey questionnaires. Also, let us know if you
would like to partiicpate in the survey.

Subject: [Ilugc] Connectiong ODBC to MySQL in Linux Server

   Hai All,

going fine. But instead of getting a 4.7GB huge file I got only a
307Mb file. What could be the reason? Below I ve given a part on my
wget-log. I would like to know whether we cannot download such huge
files using wget? If not how to download using some other tool other
than jigdo or bittorrent. I heard we can put an rsync, but will it
work for http site? Also in one of the mirror site I found that it is
impossible to download such huge files using ftp, Is it true?

From binand at gmail.com  Sun Apr 23 08:45:31 2006
From: binand at gmail.com (Binand Sethumadhavan)
Date: Sun Apr 23 12:15:39 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Unable to download debian DVD ISO
In-Reply-To: <5ef2113c0604222134i1f731b01ye3d10784b788762a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <5ef2113c0604222134i1f731b01ye3d10784b788762a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604222345j5b51f1b9ge2de346978f7e8a5@mail.gmail.com>

On 23/04/06, Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote:
> work for http site? Also in one of the mirror site I found that it is
> impossible to download such huge files using ftp, Is it true?

These kind of things depend upon both the server and client software,
and both the client and server operating system too. In this
particular case, the server told your wget that it is sending a file
of 307 MB, and that's what it got. See below:

> Length: 390,928,384 [application/octet-stream]

Right now, the server seems to be sending the full file:

Length: 4,685,895,680 [application/octet-stream]

So give it another try.

Binand

well... i did say there is a big penalty! :) that makes me think...
for these big images, shouldn't there be md5sums for every smaller
chunk, say for every 100 mb, and perhaps some tool support on the
client side to keep checking these md5sums so that we don't have to
redownload the entire stuff... just thinking aloud...

except for the tool support, i don't think it will take too much extra
time and space...

On 23/04/06, Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Length: 4,685,895,680 [application/octet-stream]
>
> No still its not giving full size image :(
> --15:51:20--
> Length: 390,928,384 [application/octet-stream]

OK, got it. Your wget is bust. Upgrade it first - it can't handle
files bigger than 4GB.

4,685,895,680 - 390,928,384 = 4,294,967,296 = 2^32

Mine's wget-1.9.1-16.fc2 (on FC2) and wget-1.10.2-0.30E (on RHEL3).
What's yours?

Binand

Date: Sun Apr 23 17:32:18 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Unable to download debian DVD ISO
In-Reply-To: <5ef2113c0604230427i55e2b76ar86260874d4dcf16d@mail.gmail.com>

	<d2a92d610604230420s78e1c126w834f41dd07364edd@mail.gmail.com>
	<5ef2113c0604230427i55e2b76ar86260874d4dcf16d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604230502y1ccee217r427e6e917cc337b5@mail.gmail.com>

On 23/04/06, Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote:
> > Mine's wget-1.9.1-16.fc2 (on FC2) and wget-1.10.2-0.30E (on RHEL3).
> > What's yours?
> I use GNU Wget 1.9.1 from debian sarge r1. I think this is the same as
> the one which you are using in FC2. Any way I ll try to upgrade it now
> and try again :)

In FC2, large file support seems to have been backported to 1.9.1 from
a later upstream version (1.10, probably):

* Fri Aug 27 2004 Karsten Hopp <karsten@redhat.de> 1.9.1-7

- clean up manpage (#117519)
- buildrequire texinfo (#123780)
- LFS patch, based on wget-LFS-20040630.patch from Leonid Petrov
  (#123524, #124628, #115348)

Check RH bugzilla:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=123524

On the other hand, in Debian Sarge, the bug is still unresolved:

http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=354989

Also, here for more details:

http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=320809

"wget 1.9 (in sarge) doesn't support large file system (LFS). This means
it cannot handle files > 2 GB. This is fixed in wget 1.10 (in etch,
sid)."

Yet another reason to ditch Debian and go for Redhat/Fedora.

HTH,

Binand

Hi
er..Please forgive me if you find this irrevelant to this list..But
since there are many software professionals around here, here goes..
Whilst roaming through the net i found this link.
http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/CollegeAdvice.html
Since I am in college i thought this article was worth a read. But one
thing hit hard on my face..Heres an excerpt

>      1. Learn how to write before graduating.
>      2. Learn C before graduating.
>      3. Learn microeconomics before graduating.
>      4. Don't blow off non-CS classes just because they're boring.
>      5. Take programming-intensive courses.
>      6. Stop worrying about all the jobs going to India.
>      7. No matter what you do, get a good summer internship.

See point no. 6...Maybe i have realised this very late, but do the
american coders see us as their nemesis???!!! are we stealing their
livelihood? followers of Reader's Digest may remember a similar article
a few issues back..
Flames away and please be gentle..I am still a kid

Sudharshan S

On 4/23/06, Prashanth Mohan <prashmohan@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Sudharshan S wrote:
> >
> >>      1. Learn how to write before graduating.
>
> >>>Start Blogging :-)


Perfect Idea!.

>>      2. Learn C before graduating.


True, Very Very True. C is completely necessary for any software job, even
if you actually end up programming in java.

>>      3. Learn microeconomics before graduating.


You do that in anna-university, but the more important topics are slighted
and we end up doing balance sheets. Infact, during our exam poeple were more
prepared (worried) about balance sheets and less about how things like
perfect competition and oligopoly and NPV etc.. works. [if its greek and
latin to you, don't worry.. when you get to learn it in college, pay more
attention to that part, rather than a single balance sheet!].

>>      4. Don't blow off non-CS classes just because they're boring.
>
> >>> ok imagine this... you keep "kappu" in Electronic Circuits. Like as if
> >>> doing that course for 1 semester isn't hard enough, doing it 2 times
> is
> >>> twice as hard. So keep that in mind when u write the Non-CS exams :D


Actually what  Mr.Spolesky means about non-CS classes is things which are
writing intensive, like "anthropology" (i guess he mentions that in the
article). Unfortunately our anna university syllabus does have such stuff in
the final year (ethics). The reason its unfortunate is this, There is a lot
of interesting stuff thats actually going on in the ethics syllabus, but in
an engineering college, you can never expect a PhD with philosophy to teach
it, and we get people who were never passionate about those subjects to
teach it. Reading Imanuel Kant is worse than reading kernel source code.

>>      5. Take programming-intensive courses.


For a computer science course, We have none of these in our syllabus.

>>      6. Stop worrying about all the jobs going to India.
>
> Why not? In a world where physical boundaries are being breached by the
> Internet, it is all about the survival of the fittest isn't it. It
> really shouldn't matter much as to where you are geographically located.


Agreed.

>>      7. No matter what you do, get a good summer internship.
>
> This is tough! From personal experience... you should start applying
> early ;-)


Agreed again. One good place to start if you are a 2nd year is AU-KBC center
at MIT. and then you can apply for a whole series of internships that come
around during your even semester. Starting from Jawaharlal Nehru Center for
Advanced Scientific Research, IISC, IIT-M, IIMS, etc.. etc..

From raamanp at yahoo.co.in  Mon Apr 24 01:43:05 2006
From: raamanp at yahoo.co.in (Raman.P)
Date: Mon Apr 24 06:13:20 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Unable to download debian DVD ISO
In-Reply-To: <5ef2113c0604230427i55e2b76ar86260874d4dcf16d@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060424004305.99061.qmail@web8608.mail.in.yahoo.com>

--- Senthil Kumaran S <stylesen@gmail.com> wrote:

> > Mine's wget-1.9.1-16.fc2 (on FC2) and wget-1.10.2-0.30E (on
> RHEL3).
> > What's yours?
> I use GNU Wget 1.9.1 from debian sarge r1. 
You are on debian and still trying to download whole iso? why? you
should use jigdo. 
Jigdo downloads individual packages and builds the iso. If old cd
images/cds you already have contains some packages which are not
changed  in the iso you are downloading, jigdo will use local copy
thus saving time and bandwidth. Thus you will not face a situation to
discard 300mb and download whole iso just because last few bits were
missing.

In fact even a partly downloded iso can be mounted and told to jigdo
to use. It will use what ever package it can recover from this.

Jigdo is yet another reason to stay/migrate with/to debian

Raman.p

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Mon Apr 24 10:38:32 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Mon Apr 24 10:29:20 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FYI: Digital Certificates in Inidan Gov
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604241034290.696-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Saswata Banerjee 

I attended a lecture at Indian Merchants Chambers yesterday on the new
government rule called MCA-21. The new rule provides that all document
sumbitted to the Ministry of Company Affaires now needs to be given in
digital form only. They will no longer accept physical documents.
Further, each of these documents will have to have a digital signature
of the persons who were earlier required to sign the physical
documents.

This is the first step to moving all governement documents to digital
form and save huge time and cost of users now wasted in standing in
line and submitting documents to the government.  The next will be Tax
authorities, followed by Excise and Customs. Land Records are expected
to be next thereafter.

There are 7 companies in India who are authorised to issue digital
certificates recorgnised under the Information Technology Act. TCS is
one who was present at the seminar and demonstrated the use of the
digital certificates. For those who have not used them, these are
stored by TCS on USB Tokens, which look like USB Pen drives but are
read-only 32KB drives with processors built in. You are supposed to
insert in the token in the UCB port and then ask the Online-Form to
pick up the digital certificate from the token and add it to the
document to submit to the government.

These certificates are based on 128 bit encryption and PKI.

TCS assured me that it is designed to work both on Linux and Mac in
addition to Windows and that they are including the relevant drivers
with the token.  However, the additional software tools they are
providing for automating digital signatures on other documents will
work only on Windows. I would like to know if any of you have used the
Digital Siganture / Digital Certificates that is being issued under
MCA-21 and can confirm that it works properly on Linux.

The other providers of Digital Certificates includes MTNL. While TCS
is charging Rs. 2075 for a 1 year valid certificate, MTNL is charging
Rs. 350. They are sending it to you on email !! Ofcourse, they are
doing this only at Malabar Hill Exchange and you have to go personally
to their office and they will verify that you are the person whose
name is on the form and your address, photo, etc.

I do not know much on Digital Certificates. However with this becoming
a major part of commercial and business transactions, I hope what the
government is doing does not work only on Windows. If necessary, we
(or perhaps FSF) will need to initiate a dialog with the government.

In the next year, it is estimated that just government requirment will
result in over 1 million digital certificates being issued. I think
the actual figure will be close to 5 million as more government
depatments like Income Tax, Sales Tax, Excise and Customs departments
move to "digital documents only" mode. (Just imagine - if every shop
keeper needs to file his sales tax returns online and needs a digital
certificate to be able to upload the return to the government). It
would be very important for us to ensure that Linux gets supported in
the process.

Regards
Saswata

From manokaran at gmail.com  Mon Apr 24 11:48:38 2006
From: manokaran at gmail.com (Mano)
Date: Mon Apr 24 11:48:46 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FYI: Digital Certificates in Inidan Gov
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604241034290.696-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

On 4/24/06, Bharathi Subramanian <sbharathi@midascomm.com> wrote:
>
> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> From: Saswata Banerjee
>
> For those who have not used them, these are
> stored by TCS on USB Tokens, which look like USB Pen drives but are
> read-only 32KB drives with processors built in. You are supposed to
> insert in the token in the UCB port and then ask the Online-Form to
> pick up the digital certificate from the token and add it to the
> document to submit to the government.
>

I guess they have the users private key on an ordinary USB device. Don't get
the part about 32KB drive with built in processor!! hogwash?

It doesn't matter where it is stored as long as one can ensure its not
stolen! Am sure gpg can very well be used on linux.

regds

ark; professionals built the Titanic!

> >>      3. Learn microeconomics before graduating.
>
> You do that in anna-university, but the more important topics are slighted
> and we end up doing balance sheets. Infact, during our exam poeple were more

Hmm... I'm curious - what's the text book prescribed at AU for the
Economics course? We had: http://tinyurl.com/pxtvt (link to Amazon) as
the text, and it is one of the most lucidly written textbooks I have
ever had the pleasure to read.

What the original article implies (and seems to have been missed in
this thread) is that the student should take the initiative to learn
Economics. It is after all, a fascinating subject whose principles are
so simple that they can be mastered with a few hours of reading.

Lastly, learning a bit of macroeconomics will help you understand the
economic forces that are causing point #6, why "all the jobs are going
to India".

Apart from Economics, I'd add Statistics to the list of "must-learn"
subjects at engineering college.

> an engineering college, you can never expect a PhD with philosophy to teach
> it, and we get people who were never passionate about those subjects to
> teach it.

Ah. The advantages of studying in an IIT, where every faculty member
is a PhD. Subjects like Psychology, Metallurgy etc. can all be
fascinating if taught by the right kind of person.

Binand

satisfying the internal demand they seep through to the A & EU? Heck. We are
a billion ourselves... we outnumber the A & EU put together - meaning we are
a bigger market. So. IMO, we need not worry about competition. Nor China. We
only have to  focus on catering to our own demand. Design and build for our
market. Not blindly copy goods built for other markets.

Like CK Prahalad asked in some meeting of industry captains (parapharasing):
Water is scarce in India. So why do you still make soap that needs water!
Why not make a product that will clean but still not need water? Design
products for the market. Don't blindly copy what was designed for the
western market.

Remember, India was the country where the metaphoric milk and honey flowed
on the streets till about 16th century AD and it was every travellers dream
to visit India!

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Mon Apr 24 14:48:35 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Mon Apr 24 14:55:22 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux application dependency library listing
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD35A@mail.esn.co.in>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD35A@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170604240218j5a28a1acp541734d9233823d8@mail.gmail.com>

> # xxx gcc
> Will show all the libraries used by the GCC executable.

ldd gcc

or

/lib/ld-<version>.so --list /usr/bin/gcc

note that this will show only the libraries which are loaded at
startup. the program can choose to load libraries at runtime. these
wont be included in this list. you can get all the loaded libraries at
any point during the execution of the process by

cat /proc/<pid>/maps | grep ' r-xp .*\.so[0-9.]*$'

it moves on...

--
April 1: This is the day upon which we are reminded of
what we are on the other three hundred and sixty-four.
          -- Mark Twain, "Pudd'nhead Wilson's Calendar"

Young boy, This is how god has designed the world:

"Every morning in the Forest, a Gazelle wakes up. It knows that it has
to run faster than the fastest Lion in the forest, or it will be killed by
the Lion. In the same forest every morning, a Lion wakes up. It knows that
it must at least outrun the slowest Gazelle in the  forest or it will starve
to death. It doesn't matter whether you are a Lion or a Gazelle... when the
sun comes up, you better be running."

>> do the American coders see us as their Nemesis???!!!
They see us and the Chinese,  as how the Gazelle sees the Lion.

>>I am worried!

Well. You don't have to. Understand this.



1. America is a super power.

2. The critical factors to be  a super power is to have large / strong
business enterprises with advanced technologies and a superior and an
un-challengeable army.

3. In the 21st century, IT, BT, EP etc play a very influential role in
determining the superiority of almost everything.

4.American younger generation has lived in all the comforts for ages
forgetting the importance of staying FIT. Most of them are dump now.

5. The article you mentioned is a wake up call for those  young
Americans. Actually
it is not for you.

6.The reason for this movement of work is Superiority of workmanship. (the
low price is only an additional advantage)

6.The work will move to who ever is best in doing that. If you are good in
doing that work, it will be moved to you. If a tribe in trobrian island is
able to do it better than you, it will be moved to him.

7.If the work is not moved the superior, then America will slowly loose the
technical superiority lead and, America will be moved ; from enjoying the
status of a super power. That is the nature's law.(Note that man who is
refusing to give the work to an American is also an American)

9. So It doesn't matter whether you are a Indian or an American... when the
sun comes up, you better be running and stay FIT. Always.

10.If you are still confused read, Bhagavath Gita chapter starting" Why are
you Worrying??"

doing for the course. Its a good book, but its just a text-book. A
collection facts, nothing more. There aren't interesting arguments that
leave you thinking about it after you've closed. it isn't something that
would make you change your career from computer science to economice because
it greatly increased your passion for the subject. There is nothing of the
sort in the book. plain facts thats all.

Not, really necessary. Microeconomics is fine, but when you actually learn
macro-economics you end up learning a lot of necessary stuff for
understanding macro-economics itself, but not really necessary in an
every-day computer programmer life-cycle. (Except when you are desinging
something like pay-pal which end up causing changes so big, that you need to
understand some macro-economics to totally understand whats going on).

From alexander at collab.net  Mon Apr 24 16:47:32 2006
From: alexander at collab.net (Alexander Thomas)
Date: Mon Apr 24 16:47:31 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux application dependency library listing
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD367@mail.esn.co.in>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD367@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <1145877452.3716.21.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2006-04-24 at 14:53 +0530, Mukund JB. wrote:
> Thanks I found that; 
> 
> I wanted this for the purpose of checking the dependencies for gcc. 
> 
> i.e. When I have to install a pre-build toolchain, what will I endup
> installing apart from gcc?
> 
I don;t really understand your requirement, why we need gcc for a
already build package?

> I found, only glibc is the only library that gcc will depend on? Is it
> so? If that is case what, where does the binutils come into picture.

GNU toolchain is a broad name give to a set of tools which includes make
system, compiler, debuggers, linkers, assemblers etc. Binutils just one
package in the toolchain for linkers, assemblers and it contains tools
like as, ld, ranlib, ar, nm ......

-AT



-AT

From alexander at collab.net  Mon Apr 24 17:05:59 2006
From: alexander at collab.net (Alexander Thomas)
Date: Mon Apr 24 17:05:55 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux application dependency library listing
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD39A@mail.esn.co.in>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD39A@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <1145878559.3716.30.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Mon, 2006-04-24 at 16:53 +0530, Mukund JB. wrote:
> Dear Alexander,
> 
> As far as I know, The GCC will invoke the ranlib, ar, nm and other tools
> from it when required in the process of building an obj or executable
> file. I was just trying to understand whether the GCC has there tools
> inbuilt or it calls through something like scripts.
> 

AFAIK, GCC will not run ranlib or any other binutils on the executable
it produces, Its left to the user. As an example if I want to create a
archive file, either I run the ar command separately on the gcc output
files or will notify the make system to do so.

-AT

which are written.

how?
TOC is updated and carried forward in every next session writing.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Mon Apr 24 07:59:23 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon Apr 24 20:29:47 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] instead of lilo what to give for grub loader
In-Reply-To: <34e9e86b0604240628y5ba3796dl20f465f93f84cb50@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060424145923.95212.qmail@web50215.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi Selvakumar,

--- selvakumar ramasamy <rselvakumar81@gmail.com>
wrote:
> i am have Redhat 9, installed in my system along
> with window98 and windowxp.

So, you will be using grub bootloader, by default.

> i made change in kernel configuration after that i
> gave
> 
> make bzImage
> cp (copied the bzImage to the image i had already)

Why? You can still have a separate entry for this
newly compiled kernel.

You can remove the previous kernel provided you are
happy with your newly compiled kernel.
 
> after that i gave lilo it says come thing, 

You are using grub. Why did you give lilo?

> i didn't
> remember that.

Ahh! ok. Remember to remember the golden words:

"I will _be_ conscious of what I am doing when I am
root".

> i say some kernel panic error, 

1. It could be that your path to the new kernel is
incorrect.

 OR

2. In your newly compiled kernel you don't have file
system support for the file-system used in the hard
disk.

> it not at all
> entering into the system.

No problem. Learn how to debug from grub prompt.

When grub loads, you can change its arguments on the
fly. Press 'e' to edit the highlighted option. You can
edit whichever line you want and see if it boots.
Google for some HOWTOs and tutorials.

> the problem it unable to find the path to the new
> kernel image

Check your path.
 
> my system linux loader is grub.

Yes.

> what i have to do now, to re back to original.
> i had some important materials in the system.

Your data is intact. Its just that your kernel is not
booting.

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

From mukundjb at esntechnologies.co.in  Mon Apr 24 21:01:25 2006
From: mukundjb at esntechnologies.co.in (Mukund JB.)
Date: Mon Apr 24 21:00:45 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Problem Simulating REMOVAL Media
Message-ID: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD3E0@mail.esn.co.in>

 

Dear Linux Kernel Govers,

 

Here I am making an attempt to simulate the Removable media in a Simple
block driver module.

It results in a segmentation fault raising the kernel module count to 1
which makes me to reboot it.

 

I am doing the following when trying to simulate the Removable media:

 

/******* Simple block Driver request ********/ 

static void sbd_request(request_queue_t *q)

{

    struct request *req;

    int status;

 

    while ((req = elv_next_request(q)) != NULL) {

      if (! blk_fs_request(req)) {

          printk (KERN_NOTICE "Skip non-CMD request\n");

          end_request(req, 0);

          continue;

      }

 

      /* Simple memcpy based on the request ; 

   Returns success or failure which is passed to
end_that_request_first() */

      status = sbd_transfer(&Device, req->sector,
req->current_nr_sectors,

                  req->buffer, rq_data_dir(req));

 

      // end_request(req, 1);

      if(!end_that_request_first(req, status, req->current_nr_sectors))
{

                  blkdev_dequeue_request(req);

                  end_that_request_last(req);

            }

    }

 

I issue an IOCTL from the application after the module is loaded and
memory device is mounted.

The IOCTL code executed is as follows:

 

/* Simulate the Removal Media Disk */

Case REMOVE_MOUNTED_DISK:

 

            if(Device.bdev)

                  invalidate_bdev(Device.bdev,1);

 

            del_gendisk(Device.gd);

            put_disk(Device.gd);

            blk_cleanup_queue(Queue);

            vfree(Device.data);

            return 0;

 

After this, I get a segmentation fault either when I issue a 

#ls /mnt

OR

When I try to unload the driver module?

 

Result is module cannot be unloaded, and some times it hangs the console
terminal.

 

Regards,

Mukund Jampala

Hi Arunkumar,

--- Arunkumar Arumugam <arshara@gmail.com> wrote:

For Network programming, I'd definitely recommend:

Richard Stevens. 1998. UNIX Network Programming. (2nd
ed.). Prentice Hall.

 http://www.kohala.com/start/unpv12e.html
 
For the GNU/Linux implementation, check Dan Kegel's
code examples:

 http://kegel.com/unpv1/

Have fun,

On 24/04/06, vishnu vyas <vishnuvyas@gmail.com> wrote:
> Unfortunately, this "text-book" stlye super boring book was what we ended up
> doing for the course. Its a good book, but its just a text-book. A
>
> http://www.gobookshopping.com/BookDetails.asp?bookid=226651&cateid=

For some time, I thought your comment "super boring" was directed at
Samuelson :) Now that I have my perspective restored, let me reiterate
a pet peeve of mine - that Indian textbook authors somehow ALWAYS
manage to get their target audience - the students - completely
disinterested in the subject. The best thing about studying in IIT was
that all the foundation courses - semesters 1-3 and part of semester 4
- had such interestingly written text books - books that I know people
still cherish and occupy prominent positions in their bookshelves.
Recently - almost 12 years after I was done with all Mathematics
courses - I simply couldn't resist buying the latest edition of
Kreyszig, just for the heck of it - for the pleasure of reading
through a well-written textbook. On the other hand, I still dread my
pre-degree course's Mathematics text books (Calicut University) - each
one a horror story in itself.

Binand

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Wed Apr 26 11:05:04 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Wed Apr 26 11:03:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] FYI: Would you like to mentor ...
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604261101410.11555-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

-------- Original Message --------
Subject: Would you like to mentor a student paid to contribute to
         your package?
Date   : Tue, 25 Apr 2006 14:56:31 -0400
>From   : Richard Stallman 

The GNU Project is participating in Google's Summer of Code program.
(See http://code.google.com/soc/mentorfaq.html for details.)  In
summary:

 * Summer of Code 2006 is a program that offers student developers
   stipends to work on development of free software.

 * The FSF will be paid $500 per project, too.

 * We need people to volunteer to mentor these students, and also
   people to evaluate other ideas that students may suggest.

 * Payment to the student is contingent upon feedback by the mentor.

 * There is no requirement that the finished code be included in the
   package itself, but goal is to get code we want to use.

 * For FSF-copyrighted GNU packages, we will ask the student to sign
   the usual copyright assignment before getting paid, to make sure
   there will be no legal obstacle to using his code.

If you are willing to mentor one or more projects, this could be of
great use to the GNU Project -- it would introduce new volunteers to
your package's code base, get a little funds for the FSF, and enhance
the GNU operating system.

Before you volunteer to be a mentor, please make sure you can actually
spare the time to do the work; having mentors become unresponsive or
drop out would be very bad.  It is important for projects to be
feasible for a good student-level hacker to do in 2 or 3 months;
nothing super large.

It is ok if you talk with student candidates that you already know are
capable, to plan projects with them.  That is a good way to produce
projects that are really likely to get done, and done well.

To volunteer as a mentor, please send email to
<summer-of-code@gnu.org>.  Please describe the student projects you
offer to mentor, and for each one, say which GNU package it will
enhance.

We need to find a "backup mentor" for each project; the backup mentor
is someone who will take over in case you become busy, sick, or
otherwise unavailable.  If you can think of any obvious suggestions
for backup mentors for your projects, please mention the suggestions
in your mail.  (We consider these suggestions are tentative, so you
can mention them first, then ask them if they are available.)  But if
you can't think of anyone, please suggest your project anyway.  We
will look for a suitable backup mentor.

James Youngman <jay@gnu.org> will be taking care of accumulating the
offers and putting them in our web site, but he could use one or two
people to help.  If you are willing to help, please write to
<summer-of-code@gnu.org>.

HTH :)
--
Bharathi S

We Novatium, have requirements for the following positions.

Position: Linux/Unix Developer
Experience: 3 to 4 years
Location: Bangalore/chennai
Skills:
C, Linux/Unix internals, system programming experience, fantastic
problem solving ability.
Description:
The person should have at least 3 years of industry experience in all
the above mentioned skills. It is very important the person has
excellent problem solving ability. The person should have good knowledge
of using C in developing system level programs. A good knowledge of X
Server and X library internals is required.


Position: Linux/Unix Development lead
Experience: 4 to 6 years
Location: Bangalore
Skills:
C, Linux/Unix internals, system programming experience, fantastic
problem solving ability, leadership abilities
Description:
The person should have at least 5 years of industry experience in all
the above mentioned skills. It is very important the person has
excellent problem solving ability. The person should have good knowledge
of using C in developing system level programs. A good knowledge of X
Server and X library internals is required. The person should have prior
experience in leading teams of at least 4 persons.

Interested candidates, please mail your CVs to pravitta@novatium.com .

Hi All
I am trying to work on a block driver.

I have  a read call from my user test file and is as follows:
read(fd, ubuf, 1024));

In the driver: the request ( read_sector )   gets invoked with 
parameters specified  in current request.
cur_req(&blkdrv, sector,  CURRENT->current_nr_sectors,  CURRENT->buffer);

Anyone pl tell how the the "no:of bytes"  parameter ( 3rd arg) in read 
call gets converted to sector( starting sector from where to  read  )   
& current_nr_sectors (number of sectors to read)
in the driver.

Can i give the sector number from where to start  and number of sectors 
to read from user test file.

From madan at collab.net  Wed Apr 26 16:41:59 2006
From: madan at collab.net (Madan U Sreenivasan)
Date: Wed Apr 26 16:11:12 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] CVS vs ClearCase
Message-ID: <op.s8l319huh4mhz7@localhost>

On Wed, 26 Apr 2006 15:56:24 +0530, <ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:

> Hai lugies,
>          Have any of you guys used CVS and/or Rational's
> ClearCase for
> Version Control of your software products.
>          I would like to know what are the advantages,
> disadvantages in
> both the system.

Too far and varied to compare... also, svn is the norm (not CVS)  
nowadays.... so am adding svn to the list below....

am giving a try at comparison....

CVS : centralized
SVN : centralized (svk is distributed)
CC : centalized and distributed(as an option)

CVS : no merge tracking
SVN : feature under development (there are third party options, tho)
CC : has merge tracking facilities

CVS : no atomic commits
SVN : has atomic commits
CC : has atomic commits

CVS : uses pserver or cvsnt for network based access
SVN : uses http:// , svn:// and file:// based access
CC : not sure, but I think uses some properietary method

CVS : open source
SVN : open source
CC : properietary

CVS : free
SVN : free
CC : paid and expensive

     Do you have anything in specific to compare?

Regards,
Madan.
From codeshepherd at gmail.com  Wed Apr 26 16:23:06 2006
From: codeshepherd at gmail.com (Deepan Chakravarthy)
Date: Wed Apr 26 16:21:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux application dependency library listing
In-Reply-To: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD367@mail.esn.co.in>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD367@mail.esn.co.in>
Message-ID: <444F5112.8030408@gmail.com>


>>> Dear Linux Team,
>>>
>>> There is a Linux command for knowing the list of library dependencies
>>> for an executable application.
>>> Can someone give me some pointer on command?
>>>
>>>       

Used *ldd* to find all the shared library dependencies. You can also use 
*nm* to find the list of objects from object files. This is very useful 
when you have all libraries in write place but some dependent symbols 
not in right place.
Thanks
Deepan Chakravarthy N
www.codeshepherd.com

From codeshepherd at gmail.com  Wed Apr 26 16:26:19 2006
From: codeshepherd at gmail.com (Deepan Chakravarthy)
Date: Wed Apr 26 16:25:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux application dependency library listing
In-Reply-To: <9a9bfc170604240218j5a28a1acp541734d9233823d8@mail.gmail.com>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD35A@mail.esn.co.in>

Message-ID: <444F51D3.7050307@gmail.com>

Ramkumar R wrote:
>> # xxx gcc
>> Will show all the libraries used by the GCC executable.
>>     
>
> ldd gcc
>
> or
>
> /lib/ld-<version>.so --list /usr/bin/gcc
>   
This is interesting.  But i dont understand how you can use a shared 
object file as a standalone executable.   Ramkumar , can you explain 
this more.

Thanks
Deepan Chakravarthy N
www.codeshepherd.com
> note that this will show only the libraries which are loaded at
> startup. the program can choose to load libraries at runtime. these
> wont be included in this list. you can get all the loaded libraries at
> any point during the execution of the process by
>
> cat /proc/<pid>/maps | grep ' r-xp .*\.so[0-9.]*$'
>
> it moves on...
>
> --

>> i.e. When I have to install a pre-build toolchain, what will I endup
>> installing apart from gcc?
>>
>>     
> I don;t really understand your requirement, why we need gcc for a
> already build package?
>
>   
>> I found, only glibc is the only library that gcc will depend on? Is it
>> so? If that is case what, where does the binutils come into picture.

>
> GNU toolchain is a broad name give to a set of tools which includes make
> system, compiler, debuggers, linkers, assemblers etc. Binutils just one
> package in the toolchain for linkers, assemblers and it contains tools
> like as, ld, ranlib, ar, nm ......
>

From andyetitmoves at gmail.com  Wed Apr 26 16:35:40 2006
From: andyetitmoves at gmail.com (Ramkumar R)
Date: Wed Apr 26 16:35:50 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Linux application dependency library listing
In-Reply-To: <444F51D3.7050307@gmail.com>
References: <3AEC1E10243A314391FE9C01CD65429B3FD35A@mail.esn.co.in>
	<9a9bfc170604240218j5a28a1acp541734d9233823d8@mail.gmail.com>
	<444F51D3.7050307@gmail.com>
Message-ID: <9a9bfc170604260405g6dca3f1ax8838169966638988@mail.gmail.com>

> This is interesting.  But i dont understand how you can use a shared
> object file as a standalone executable.   Ramkumar , can you explain
> this more.

afaik, elf makes little distinction between shared object libraries
and executables. wat u need is just a table of relocatable function
symbols in an elf object for it to be used by some other program. in
addition, if there is a special symbol indicating the start of the
program, it is capable of being run, and that function is invoked on
execution, and it calls main in the code you write.

btw, because u asked... try this as well :)

/lib/libc.so.<version> --help

it moves on...

--
April 1: This is the day upon which we are reminded of
what we are on the other three hundred and sixty-four.
          -- Mark Twain, "Pudd'nhead Wilson's Calendar"

From radkrishnan at gmail.com  Wed Apr 26 17:14:58 2006
From: radkrishnan at gmail.com (radha)
Date: Wed Apr 26 17:16:04 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Installing oracle_xe on fedora core 3
Message-ID: <000801c66926$da8f83b0$e9a8a8c0@dotneto>

hi
After installation 

1. Start Oracle Database XE.
Click the Application menu (on Gnome) or the K menu (on KDE), then point
to Oracle Database 10g Express Edition, and then Go To Database Home
Page.
(will also open in a browser for http://127.0.0.1:8080/apex address but i am gettion conection refused  message)

2. In the Database Login page, log in as SYSTEM, enter the password, and then 
click Login.
3. In the Oracle Database XE home page, click Administration.
4. Under Tasks, click Manage HTTP Access.
5. Under Manage HTTP Access, select Available from local server and remove
clients.
6. Click Apply Changes. 
- Hide quoted text -

Date: Wed Apr 26 18:27:03 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Installing oracle_xe on fedora core 3
In-Reply-To: <000801c66926$da8f83b0$e9a8a8c0@dotneto>
References: <000801c66926$da8f83b0$e9a8a8c0@dotneto>
Message-ID: <d2a92d610604260556w4f58f0edr606ebed2440f8027@mail.gmail.com>

On 26/04/06, radha <radkrishnan@gmail.com> wrote:
> 1. Start Oracle Database XE.
> Click the Application menu (on Gnome) or the K menu (on KDE), then point
> to Oracle Database 10g Express Edition, and then Go To Database Home
> Page.
> (will also open in a browser for http://127.0.0.1:8080/apex address but i am gettion conection refused  message)

I think you need to enable and start the HTTP server (steps 4-6 below,
probably - haven't used 10g EE, and certainly never have managed
Oracle via a web interface).

Binand

> 4. Under Tasks, click Manage HTTP Access.
> 5. Under Manage HTTP Access, select Available from local server and remove
> clients.
> 6. Click Apply Changes.

From: "Madan U Sreenivasan" <madan@collab.net>
To: "Binand Sethumadhavan" <binand@gmail.com>
Cc:
Subject: Re: [Ilugc] [OT] CVS vs ClearCase
Date: Wed, 26 Apr 2006 19:55:01 +0530

On Wed, 26 Apr 2006 18:21:36 +0530, Binand Sethumadhavan
<binand@gmail.com> wrote:

> On 26/04/06, Madan U Sreenivasan <madan@collab.net> wrote:
>> Too far and varied to compare... also, svn is the norm (not CVS)
>> nowadays.... so am adding svn to the list below....
>
> Curious why you say that. Sourceforge is still on CVS,

what do you mean? the sourceforge project is on cvs? or that with
sourceforge, you only have cvs as a vc option? (the latter is not true).
If you mean the sourceforge code is not on cvs, well, I do not know about
the validity of that statement, but even so, its just a choice people
make. But am sure its not a conscious happy choice... (cvs is almost
no-more-dev nowadays, so many bugs and so little done on them, oh, wont I
miss directory versioning and atomic commits on CVS?)... its just a matter
of time...

> so do you have
> any authoritative references that show a large-scale migration to SVN?


Sure, the following are some of the major projects that have migrated....

gcc
kde
openoffice (http://wiki.services.openoffice.org/wiki/SVNMigration)
gnome is migrating (they are facing some date-version issues during
conversion)
sourceforge provides svn as an option too....
(http://sourceforge.net/docs/E09/en/) just that they cant force every
project into svn...

    I forget where... but sometime in mid-2005, I read a survey which
indicated that svn has overtaken cvs in terms of number of opensource
projects using it.

    Again, svn is meant to be all that cvs is, plus more.... am only
surprised that you are contesting my statement... its more of a 'as a
matter of fact' than a revolutionary statement that I made.... :)

    Feel free to engage me in a dialouge if you strongly feel otherwise.

Regards,
Madan.

From prem at songbirdtech.com  Wed Apr 26 20:52:45 2006
From: prem at songbirdtech.com (Prem Kurian Philip)
Date: Wed Apr 26 20:53:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] svn, cvs and darcs
Message-ID: <2591.61.247.255.57.1146064965.squirrel@www.songbirdtech.com>

>Gopalarathnam Venkatesan wrote:

>>I use Mercurial [http://www.selenic.com/mercurial/wiki/index.cgi] for
>>my personal projects. It rocks :)
>>
>>
>>
>That reminds me. Is anybody using darcs or svk? Can anybody share
>experiences on those vis-a-vis svn?


>Vamsee.

I have used darcs. Quite good and very easy to setup and use. The approach
is different from svn, CVS etc and it is completely distributed. The way
that darcs handles patches is wonderful. However the problem is that darcs
is written in haskell and haskell compiler is also written in haskell :)
this sometimes complicates things when you don't have darcs binaries for
your platform and have to compile it from source.

The other problem with darcs is the fact there is very limited tool
support  - Also, there are no gui tools that I am aware off.

Regards,
PK

say a expert is defined as per answers.com
   1.  A person with a high degree of skill in or knowledge of a
certain subject.
   2.  a. The highest grade that can be achieved in marksmanship.
        b. A person who has achieved this grade.

Having, involving, or demonstrating great skill, dexterity, or
knowledge as the result of experience or training. See synonyms at
proficient

in terms of FOSS, if u know any of the Open Source Tool's
functionalit... then u r considered as expert in that.

find the right FOSS experts is just similar to finding a sysadmin.
because sysadmin job is smaller in number than the programming job.
same applies and this answers ur question. i agree that all experts
are always scarce. but in that finding FOSS experts is much more
difficult.

From manokaran at gmail.com  Wed Apr 26 12:09:24 2006
From: manokaran at gmail.com (Mano)
Date: Thu Apr 27 02:23:07 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] I am worried!
In-Reply-To: <d2a92d610604250406v5886171an4380389965591095@mail.gmail.com>
References: <1145811742.9400.10.camel@tuxbox.ubergeek> <444BC120.603@gmail.com>

	<8e6637b50604240358j5009b744q62da159c25dc36c8@mail.gmail.com>
	<d2a92d610604250406v5886171an4380389965591095@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <7bf1bec50604252339i47d9fc6ayb6085b3edcf077ec@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/25/06, Binand Sethumadhavan <binand@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Recently - almost 12 years after I was done with all Mathematics
> courses - I simply couldn't resist buying the latest edition of
> Kreyszig, just for the heck of it - for the pleasure of reading
> through a well-written textbook. On the other hand, I still dread my
> pre-degree course's Mathematics text books (Calicut University) - each
> one a horror story in itself.
>

I wish I knew about 'What is Mathematics' by R. Courant when I was in
college! Its a 50 yr old manuscript which gives a superb perspective to the
field of math. Not much about discrete math though. So, the 'hard core'
programmers might wonder whats in it for them! But my advice is: dont
willingly wear blinders. IMO, this should be the introductory text to math
for every engineering student.

To give you a flavour of its age, it  talks about the difficulties in
proving the Fermat's last theorem and the four colour theorem! Though, the
revised edition talks about the proofs (which came much later..... I think
after the original authors expired!) of these in the appendices.

The book is published by Oxford Univ Press, next to USIS. You will have to
register for it and they will inform you when it is available - takes a
couple of months. But well worth the wait.

regds

--
Never be afraid to try something new. Remember, amateurs built the
ark; professionals built the Titanic!

From sbharathi at MidasComm.Com  Thu Apr 27 10:24:05 2006
From: sbharathi at MidasComm.Com (Bharathi Subramanian)
Date: Thu Apr 27 10:14:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] DFS: Debian From Scratch
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0604261315260.12910-100000@bharathi.midascomm.com>

Hi,

I hope many of us know about the LFS (Linux From Scratch is a project
that provides you with step-by-step instructions for building your own
customized Linux system entirely from source.)

Here is a similar kind of project, by John Goerzen, the Debian From 
Scratch :). http://people.debian.org/~jgoerzen/dfs/html/

HTH :)
-- 
Bharathi S

According to the jabber site wildfire is 98% compliant with XMPP whereas
ejabberd is 91%. Wildfire also has asterisk integration. So integrating your
PSTN network to your LAN IM would be a possibility.

For client you can try jwChat. Its a pure ajax client.

> Hey, i think there is a big difference between LFS and DFS. I think it is

I was really surprised to see ejabberd working out of the box without any
issues!..cool....and i checked with Kopete and Gaim.Both work flawlessly. I
dont want to try jwchat as i have been instructed not to use web interface
for chatting :).

http://www.process-one.net/en/projects/ejabberd/docs.html - this link has
docs on how to install ejabberd and make it ready as server. There is a cool
video and that video helped me (the installation is so simple that you
wouldnt require any videos ;-) ).

There are many options available in ejabberd, now we are going to implement
in the server. So , now it is time to get stuck up with problems and i think
then we will learn to customize with options :).

Thank You all.

From: rajagopal.n at gmail.com (Rajagopal Natarajan)

Subject: [Ilugc] GPL and public domain software license.
Message-ID: <e0900f3e0604270402m1537e83ai4e8c7ba95b7144a@mail.gmail.com>

Hi every1,
If i modify a public domain software's code and make use of it as a part of
my softwares' code, how should I license my software under GPL? would I be
able to license different parts of my software under different licenses?
(part of it public domain and other part GPL).

--
N. Rajagopal,
Visit me at http://www.rajagopal.tk
From gopal at gopalarathnam.com  Thu Apr 27 16:54:52 2006
From: gopal at gopalarathnam.com (Gopalarathnam Venkatesan)
Date: Thu Apr 27 16:55:00 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] GPL and public domain software license.
In-Reply-To: <e0900f3e0604270402m1537e83ai4e8c7ba95b7144a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <e0900f3e0604270402m1537e83ai4e8c7ba95b7144a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4cba61b90604270424j993928fk6b0431066474856d@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/27/06, Rajagopal Natarajan <rajagopal.n@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hi every1,
> If i modify a public domain software's code and make use of it as a part of
> my softwares' code, how should I license my software under GPL? would I be
> able to license different parts of my software under different licenses?
> (part of it public domain and other part GPL).
>

GPL is viral, meaning whenever you combine it with some other license,
you'll need to release your software as GPL.

Read the GPL FAQ for more info.
http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html

--
Gopalarathnam Venkatesan
http://gopalarathnam.com/

From rajagopal.n at gmail.com  Thu Apr 27 17:00:49 2006
From: rajagopal.n at gmail.com (Rajagopal Natarajan)
Date: Thu Apr 27 17:00:57 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Help with gdb
In-Reply-To: <c0b743a40604270428u60139241k63c11e1ed2383f14@mail.gmail.com>
References: <c0b743a40604270428u60139241k63c11e1ed2383f14@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <e0900f3e0604270430g46968b58vb4311bb94a33893c@mail.gmail.com>

On 4/27/06, Bharath Narayan <bharath144@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> hi all,
> i have a program in which i create a thread to do some processing.
> when i rub the dubugger, i want to know how to switch to the thread from
> the
> current thread.


check this http://www.delorie.com/gnu/docs/gdb/gdb_25.html

GDB provides these facilities for debugging multi-thread programs:


   - automatic notification of new threads
   - `thread threadno', a command to switch among threads
   - `info threads', a command to inquire about existing threads
   - `thread apply [threadno] [all] args', a command to apply a command
   to a list of threads
   - thread-specific breakpoints





--
N. Rajagopal,
Visit me at http://www.rajagopal.tk
From madan at collab.net  Thu Apr 27 18:18:38 2006
From: madan at collab.net (Madan U Sreenivasan)
Date: Thu Apr 27 17:47:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: ilugc Digest, Vol 23, Issue 93
In-Reply-To: <20060427112737.3E7571DB266@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
References: <20060427112737.3E7571DB266@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>
Message-ID: <op.s8n27cwih4mhz7@localhost>

On Thu, 27 Apr 2006 16:57:37 +0530, <ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in> wrote:

> On 4/27/06, Rajagopal Natarajan
> <rajagopal.n@gmail.com> wrote:
>> Hi every1,
>> If i modify a public domain software's code and
> make use of it as a part of
>> my softwares' code, how should I license my
> software under GPL? would I be
>> able to license different parts of my software
> under different licenses?
>> (part of it public domain and other part GPL).
>>
> GPL is viral, meaning whenever you combine it with
> some other license,
> you'll need to release your software as GPL.
> Read the GPL FAQ for more info.
> http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html

OTOH, you can choose to use software that have apache/BSD style license  
which are NOT viral...  In which case, you can decide to apply copyright  
to certain parts and copyleft to certain parts of *your* code...

Regards,
Madan.

From lawgon at thenilgiris.com  Fri Apr 28 07:39:09 2006
From: lawgon at thenilgiris.com (Kenneth Gonsalves)
Date: Fri Apr 28 07:39:28 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] GPL and public domain software license.
In-Reply-To: <e0900f3e0604270427t3028933fqac7eaec47601b800@mail.gmail.com>
References: <e0900f3e0604270402m1537e83ai4e8c7ba95b7144a@mail.gmail.com>
	<4cba61b90604270424j993928fk6b0431066474856d@mail.gmail.com>
	<e0900f3e0604270427t3028933fqac7eaec47601b800@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <200604280739.09011.lawgon@thenilgiris.com>

On Thursday 27 Apr 2006 4:57 pm, Rajagopal Natarajan wrote:
> > GPL is viral, meaning whenever you combine it with some other
> > license, you'll need to release your software as GPL.
>
> What about the public domain license? can i license the code that
> is in public domain also in GPL?

public domain is not a license. It means that the author has given 
up his copyright. So you license your code under GPL, and in your 
license you mention xyz part of the application is public domain 
code. You cant license the public domain code, but you can license 
your modification of the public domain code under GPL

-- 
regards
kg

http://www.livejournal.com/users/lawgon
tally ho! http://avsap.org.in

From sujithkr at gmail.com  Fri Apr 28 11:03:32 2006
From: sujithkr at gmail.com (sujith nambiar)

Subject: [Ilugc] FOSS startup camp
Message-ID: <e897e46d0604272233g26e219e8o4f88481c684d2c8d@mail.gmail.com>

Dear all,

           I am glad to inform you that NRCFOSS is conducting a camp for
young engineers, who wish to start their own company in FOSS related areas.
It is a four week program, where several successful entrepreneurs, will be
sharing their ideas on starting a company and running it successfully.

The program plan :
one week of lectures, presentations and guidance in defining the startup
goal
two weeks of working towards the goal
last one week of taking stock and defining future directions

The objective of the program is to enable prospective entrepreneurs
to kickstart their Free & Open Source Software company.


For more details, please visit "http://www.au-kbc.org/nrcf/camp/" .


regards,
Sujith K.R
NRCFOSS

Hi Deepak,

On 4/27/06, deepak srinivasan <deepak86@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> hi all,
>        i am using ubuntu breezy on my pc at home.
> when i try to install packages using synaptic manager most of the
> packages are not getting marked for installtion.


Can you be specific or name any package on which this problem appears.

the reason it says is 'dependancy cannot be resolved'
> also on top of the window there is a message that if i update my
> repository i might be able to download them..


Did you add the Universe and Multiverse Repositories in your
/etc/apt/sources.list file?

After which you have to run a $sudo apt-get update

>From Synaptic: Check whether the Universe and Multiverse Repos are added.
You can do this by Settings -> Repositories


Regards,
