From navalady at gmail.com  Sat Apr 29 15:29:08 2006
From: navalady at gmail.com (nava ladi)
Date: Sat Apr 29 15:29:16 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sound problem in intel 915 +Debian 3.1 r1
Message-ID: <d05619590604290259s7e2ee2f6t6653ec3ba37532ff@mail.gmail.com>

Hi all,I have problem in intel 915 sound chipset..I have installed
Debian 3.1 r1.After installation seems that no sound card detected.The
soundchip is attached with motherboard (Intel 915 D100GGc).

I tryied with #alsaconf which fails to detect..The Kernel is 2.6.8 i
thing..#alsamixer also fails.

#alsamixer
alsamixer:  function_ctl_open failed for default : No such Device
#

All  we should do,is to load a proper sound card driver.is n't it?

I also thing that,the card type is RealTech Semiconductor Inc.
The driver looks like snd-intelx80.ko.But nothing seems to work.

I also searched in Google.i did not get relavant or moresuitale one t
my hardwae.

Help me out of this problem..?
From akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in  Sat Apr 29 16:54:07 2006
From: akumar at ee.iitm.ac.in (Kumar Appaiah)
Date: Sat Apr 29 16:40:05 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Sound problem in intel 915 +Debian 3.1 r1
In-Reply-To: <d05619590604290259s7e2ee2f6t6653ec3ba37532ff@mail.gmail.com>
References: <d05619590604290259s7e2ee2f6t6653ec3ba37532ff@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <20060429112407.GA4259@localhost>

On Sat, Apr 29, 2006 at 03:29:08PM +0530, nava ladi wrote:
> Hi all,I have problem in intel 915 sound chipset..I have installed
> Debian 3.1 r1.After installation seems that no sound card detected.The
> soundchip is attached with motherboard (Intel 915 D100GGc).
> 
> I tryied with #alsaconf which fails to detect..The Kernel is 2.6.8 i
> thing..#alsamixer also fails.
> 
> #alsamixer
> alsamixer:  function_ctl_open failed for default : No such Device
> #
> 
> All  we should do,is to load a proper sound card driver.is n't it?
> 
> I also thing that,the card type is RealTech Semiconductor Inc.
> The driver looks like snd-intelx80.ko.But nothing seems to work.

I guess the first thing you should try is to get a more recent kernel,
like 2.6.11+ as the Debian kernels have the drivers for Intel HDA
compiled in them already, IIRC.

Otherwise, get the latest ALSA drivers from
http://www.alsa-project.org ; in particular, get driver and
utilities. Then, get the kernel headers for your kernel using

apt-get install linux-headers-$(uname -r)

(In bash, $uname -r expands to the right kernel version).

Untar the alsa-drivers, run configure as 
./configure --with-kernel=/usr/src/linux-headers-$(uname -r)

Then, make; make install.

Finally, run alsaconf to select the required driver.

HTH.

Kumar
-- 
Kumar Appaiah,
462, Jamuna Hostel,
Indian Institute of Technology Madras,
Chennai - 600 036

From kmshiva at gmail.com  Sat Apr 29 19:04:24 2006
From: kmshiva at gmail.com (Shiva KM)
Date: Sat Apr 29 19:04:35 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] How to run a python program in Nokia 6600
In-Reply-To: <ed2d3c000604282158r3053f469wb5d5cccae47f302a@mail.gmail.com>
References: <ed2d3c000604282158r3053f469wb5d5cccae47f302a@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <654433ee0604290634o42d0e663l3439f2e451fd2c87@mail.gmail.com>

Hi,

> Have any one tried running a python program on nokia 6600 mobile phone. Any
> pointers to do step by step installation on phython on nokia 6600 phones.

I have got this working - is pretty nifty actually! :)

It is pretty easy to do, just download the 'sis' file and install it
as you would normally install any application on your phone - just
send the sis file to the phone from the computer using bluetooth.

Now, actually writing a program is a pain-in-the-neck! You can either
type in the program in the interactive console that comes with the
phone, but ofcourse typing in any program on the phone keypad
shouldn't attempted unless you are seriously bored!

Another option is to use the python console running on ur phone from
ur computer. This is done using the btconsole python program on the
phone, and some fooling around on the computer. I had to mess around
with minicom and such on the computer to get it working, and even when
it did, it was pretty flaky, the connection kept getting lost and all
that. Though, when it did work, it was very cool! :)

This is  however, my experience when i tried this around 6 months
back, perhaps things are better with the newer versions. For help on
using btconsole, some amount of googling should help. For more links
related to this you could probably rummage around in my bookmarks at
http://del.icio.us/kmshiva/nokia and
http://del.icio.us/kmshiva/nokia%2Bpython.

HTH.
--
Regards,
shiva
--
Do not fear to be eccentric in opinion, for every opinion now accepted
was once eccentric.

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Apr 30 02:15:49 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Sun Apr 30 14:46:15 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Tamil support: Ubuntu Dapper Beta
Message-ID: <20060430091549.60890.qmail@web50209.mail.yahoo.com>

Greetings!

I have installed Ubuntu Dapper Beta on my T41. Thanks
to Balu ("bman4344") for the quick download. 

Installation was smooth.

I am currently testing Tamil support in this distro. I
have installed ttf-indic-fonts, scim,
gnome-language-ta et. al.

* Able to use tamil keyboard input (unicode and
written tamil form) with Gedit, Gaim, Abiword, Vim and
Mozilla Firefox. 

* Gnome tamil interface is also good.

* I am not using transliteration, and don't want to
use any software that does it. Prefer to type fully in
Tamil.

* Have setup CAPS lock key to switch between US and
tamil unicode.

* &#2980; +&#3009; = &#2980;&#3009;
  &#2980; +&#3010; = &#2980;&#3010;
 which is the same as our written tamil.

* Gaim, Firefox and Gedit automatically do the above
translation as per our written tamil.

http://www.shakthimaan.com/downloads/tamil/text-editor.jpg

* In gnome-termial, when doing a cat on a tamil file,
the "dots" are printed separately, and certain
double-characters are interchanged:

http://www.shakthimaan.com/downloads/tamil/terminal.jpg

Is anyone else experiencing this in your distro?

* When I type in Abiword and export it to .html,
certain junk characters get printed before the
double-characters:

http://www.shakthimaan.com/downloads/tamil/tamil-fonts.html

1. In UTF-8, with gnome-terminal the characters, dots
get displayed separately. Is it common with other
distros or packages for tamil support? Is there any
other editor that I can use for UTF-8 tamil support
with proper display?

2. How can I generate HTML files with tamil input, or,
do I need to set anything for the junk characters
printed when Abiword (.abw) is exported to html (as
seen from the above)?

Appreciate any feedback,

Thanks,

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com

*FYI from slashdot.org

I came across Explorer Destroyer
<http://www.explorerdestroyer.com/>yesterday, which is a project that
aims to increase the market share of
Firefox in a slightly more proactive way than is usual. They provide some
code which you add to your front page which presents a banner to IE users
urging them to switch to using Firefox. As a bonus, you can potentially make
some money via Google's Firefox referral program.*

From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Apr 30 23:24:07 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon May  1 11:54:14 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Monthly reminder: Mailing list guidelines
Message-ID: <20060501062407.71574.qmail@web50213.mail.yahoo.com>

This is a monthly reminder to members of this list
about the posting guidelines. Please don't reply to
this e-mail. If you'd like to update it, do it here:

http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/List_Guidelines
(temporarily down)

1. Use a proper subject line.

2. Do not troll in the mailing list

Link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_troll

3. Use [OT] for off-topic, non-technical messages
indirectly related to FLOSS.

4. Do not top-post:

Link: http://www.caliburn.nl/topposting.html

Example of a top-post:

   Because it messes up the order in which 
   people normally read text.
   > > Why is top-posting 
   > > such a bad thing?
   Top-posting.
   > > What is the most 
   > > annoying thing in e-mail?

Always use bottom-posting.

> What is your name ?
  My name is ILUGC.

5. Do not over-quote:

Example of an over-quote:

>>> On Friday you said
>>>  blah blah blah
>> On Saturday you said
>>  foo foo foo
> On Sunday you said
>  foobar

6. Do not post HTML messages

7. Do not recycle messages

8. Do not send attachments

9. Do not attach obnoxious, nonsensical legal
disclaimers. If your company uses disclaimers, don't
use your company ID for the mailing list.

10. Do not reply to a digest. (If you are in digest
mode and want to reply to a post use ILUGC Gmane blog
interface.

Link:
http://blog.gmane.org/gmane.org.user-groups.linux.ilugc

11. Search for answers for your questions/problems in
google.com or any other search engine before posting
your query to the mailing list.

If any of the above are not clear to you, Please read
the detailed list guidelines:

Link:
http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

12. Do not post messages in all capital letters. Mails
in CAPS is considered rude and is similar to shouting
during a conversation.

13. If you or your company is into GNU/Linux
migration, or you want help into GNU/Linux migration,
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/GNU_Linux_migration
(temporarily down)

14. If you are looking for GNU/Linux distro CDs please
check here:
http://www.chennailug.org/wiki/CDs_for_Grab
(temporarily down)

15. Following these guidelines could be helpful:
http://people.debian.org/~enrico/dcg/

16. Don't send season's greetings or birthday invites
to the group. Its not mailing list etiquette.

We must use the above guidelines to maintain better
readability, proper archives, efficient bandwidth
usage, etc. 



__________________________________________________
Do You Yahoo!?
Tired of spam?  Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around 
http://mail.yahoo.com 
From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sun Apr 30 23:44:20 2006
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shakthi Kannan)
Date: Mon May  1 12:14:38 2006
Subject: [Ilugc] Tamil support: Ubuntu Dapper Beta   
Message-ID: <20060501064420.25449.qmail@web50201.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi again,

--- Shakthi Kannan earlier wrote:
> 1. In UTF-8, with gnome-terminal the characters,
dots
> get displayed separately. 

Ok, this is also seen in Gnome menus. I can live with
it.

> 2. How can I generate HTML files with tamil input

Bluefish works like a charm! 

* With UTF-8, Abiword can export .abw to .pdfs. Looks
good.

* To use TeX, download wntamil.zip created by the
Humanities and Arts Computing Center, University of
Washington, Seattle, Washington:

http://www.tug.org/tex-archive/help/Catalogue/entries/wntamil.html

The list of files are:

ftp://cam.ctan.org/tex-archive/language/tamil/wntamil/

If you have Tetex package installed, you can use the
above:

1. First run metafont on the wntml10.mf:

  mf wntml10.mf

This will create the wntml10.2602gf file.

2. Compile tamilize.c:

  gcc tamilize.c -o tamilize

3. To run the given example:

  ./tamilize readme.doc readme.tex

4. Run tex on readme.tex:

  tex readme.tex

This will create the readme.dvi file

5. To create .ps and .pdf files:

  dvips readme.dvi -o readme.ps
  ps2pdf readme.pdf

You can use evince or xpdf to view the .pdf file.

If you are interested in fonts and TeX, the following
is a fantastic metafont tutorial:

http://metafont.tutorial.free.fr/

Ubuntu rockz!

SK

--
Shakthi Kannan
http://www.shakthimaan.com
